reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off,  I personally love this game. It has given me many opportunities to make many friends with similar interests as my own and I have thoroughly enjoyed it.

For those reading this before purchasing allow me to explain the game for you at the current date of Dec 15th 2015.

RWBY: Grimm Eclipse at the current date is a hack and slash game with one campaign and four characters to play. Team RWBY. It is a very simple game with simple hack and slash combat. The game is not a very complicated game to play but that is what makes it a lot of fun with friends. It has a very quirky style just like the anime and its a nice refresher from some of the other games I play.

I have mastered all four characters skill trees and I will share my personal opinion on each character.

Characters
Ruby Rose - I feel as if Ruby is the most polished character in the game. With a very fluent movement style and a very flashy but controlled combo, she is easily my favorite to play. Her dodges and movements are designed very well where she disappears with rose petals into a roll just like enemy. Her three abilities are Crescendo, Reap and Dust Blast.

I feel as if Reap is a more useless skill compared the raw power coming from the Crescendo and Dust Blast skills.

Crescendo is a 360 covering move and can be used to massively wipe just about everything. The mastered version of Crescendo is good but in my opinion not worth the points it asks for. Ruby has a glitch that makes her 360 cover the strongest cover in the game in my opinion. After she uses it once, using it again allows her to move while charging.

Reap is, in my personal opinion, Ruby's useless move. Cleaving Reap is a very good mastery move. It does what I'd expect from a mastered move. It takes its weakness and capitalizes on it. It greatly increases the range of the move with the rocks that get thrown out as she crashes into the ground.

Dust Blast is a shot of dust power. It's kinda like shooting an explosion, you have the normal dust blast, electric, ice and fire. My personal favorite is the Electric due to the massive amount of range you get with it due to the chain lightning. It can kill up to 3 people in what shot and if you hit one, two enemies will get shocked with chain lightning. A very neat and unique effect.

Ruby's two passive abilities are Armor Piercing and Hyperballistic. Armor Piercing allows your ranged attacks to hit armored enemies like the pigs. Hyperballistic decreases how much of a combo you need to achieve a block of special towards using your abilities.


Weiss Schnee - Weiss is a very solid and powerful character. I personally like her movement the most because she has a very graceful and smooth movement style. Her dodge is a quick transition that you barely see and it's just overall a very smooth experience when playing as Snow Angel. Her three skills are Nova, Pierce and Barrage.

Nova is my favorite move with Weiss. Its a very powerful move that, when mastered, is a lot of fun to use. Supernova is the mastery of Nova and it draws in opponents as you charge the move. Unlike Ruby, you cannot move after using it, still giving Ruby the edge in this category of move.

Pierce is a pretty powerful move with a bit more viability than Ruby's Reap. It has more range and can one shot Beowolves at level 2. The negative draw back is what i call the universal range. You can only kill opponents if they are all right next to each other making the move not very viable in a lot of situations.

Barrage. Yeah.. I didn't really like this move until the mastered Ice Bolt. Ice Bolt is immensely powerful and has a very long straight AoE path. It's a really good move fitting for Weiss along with Supernova.

Weiss' passive abilities are Ice Queen and Perfect Form. Ice Queen makes her blast attacks freeze opponents. Perfect Form makes her combo meter fill 2 special bars instead of one. A very useful ability.


Blake Belladonna - A very clumsy and my least favorite character to play. Her combo is good but the air combo that she jumps into doesn't hit ground enemies like Ruby's does. She does a really really good ranged attack just by the simple shot she does. Her three abilities are Shadow Clone, Shadow Strike and Blade Beam.

Shadow Clone is Blake's first skill and is more a quick trap than an attacking skill. You usually have to wait to be surround to just quickly throw one out that doesn't kill unless two are hit. It's a pretty awkward move with less benefits compared to the next move. The Mastered forms are an ice and fire clone.

Shadow Strike is Blake's strongest monster clearing move. The second level is three clones and the mastered level is 5 clones. It can clear monsters faster than any other ability in the game. I really enjoy watching it as well, very quickly cast and very smooth will all 5 blake's coming out.

Blade Beam is Blake's strongest single target move. Granted, it can hit multiple enemies but I find it better as a single hit move. Not much else to say about it besides it is chargable and the mastered for are horizantal slashes that go through enemies.

Her two passive abilities are Frenzy and Fortunate Faunus. Frenzy makes her final combo hit do more damage and add 2 combo points instead of just one on the final hit. Fortunate Faunus gives her a random chance to get a special after an enemy dies.

Yang Xiao Long - The last playable character in the game and an all around good character. A very smooth combat style when you are dash dancing, as I call it. Dash dancing is when you are attacking and dodging at the same time, kinda looks like you are dashing so I call it dash dancing. Her three abilities are Quake, Sunbreaker and Blast Wave.

Quake is a simple 360 ability. Yang hops into the air and slams her fist causing an explosion around her. Super Quake is her mastered form cause much more damage than before. It's a typical Yang" ability.

Sunbreaker is her next ability and with a really cool name. It is really fun to use and is an uppercut into the sky. This causes yang to get a firey hair affect
date:
which I'm not quite sure what it does but it does look pretty cool. The mastered form hits 3 times on her way up into the air.

Blast Wave.. sucks. It's just slow and requires perfect spacing to land. Mastering this move sucks and the mastered form extends the range a bit but still not worth it in my eyes.

Yangs passive abilities are Second Wind and Brawler. Second Wing is the best ability in the game. When Yang loses all her aura she instantly refills all special points on a 30 second cooldown. Brawler makes it so she can take one hit before losing her combo
recommended:
a pretty nice passive but nothing compared to Second Wind.


Glitches I have ran across:
Ruby's Crescendo Movement. As stated above in her skill list.
Revival Glitch. When you are downed next to a teammate you can still revive each other.

Additions I want to see:
A large cast of characters to play as. The more the merrier. I love this game and I think having a large variety of characters to play as would make it amazing.

A couple of ideas:

Partnership Buffs: Some games have this
hoursPlayed:
where you pick two characters and depending on your team depends on your buffs.
Ex. Nora and Ren - Flower Power +10% Aura Regeneration

A stat menu of some sorts in the menu before a game starts.

Just a few ideas for you; I can't wait to see what you guys do with this game!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just played through the entire campaign with all four characters and here's my thoughts. I'll breakdown each character's gameplay further down.

FIRST THOUGHTS:
Starting off, it's aesthetically very much like the anime. The voice acting is very good, as expected, but can easily be drowned out by the chaos of battle. The controls are easy enough to pick up to start bashing away at things. Though, in order to survive, you'll need to learn how to time your dodges effectively [Shift]; otherwise you'll be on the ground very quickly. Sounds can be a little repetitive and overbearing at times (I'm looking at you, Blake), but it's still early access.

PROGRESSION:
Yes, there is a progression system. Well, more like an in-game achievement system with in-game rewards. As for those claiming there is no progression system, that's half true. Your character LEVEL does not save. You'll be starting the campaign over again at level one. However, your talent unlocking progress DOES save. For example, 0/100 kills needed with a specific ability with a character can be built up through multiple playthroughs.

Achieving the level cap of 10 in a single playthrough to unlock their 'master' talent can be tough, and may require multiple playthroughs after unlocking some talents to help secure kills. That's where the urge to keep playing comes into play. Once talents are unlocked, they are unlocked for good, and can be purchased with attribute points without needing to unlock them again. Not a bad system, but may not be for everyone. I was only able to finally get to level 10 as Yang due to my allies dying while I cleaned up the battlefield, on multiple occasions.

MECHANICS:
It's very much a hack and slash, and does a very good job at it. Aside from there being only one button to attack with, the combat can get dull rather quickly. That is, unless you tie it together with dodges in-between, which resets the combo, or pressing right mouse-click during the combo to interrupt it with some sort of knock-back or finisher. There is no visual 'lock-on' as of yet, so its hard to stick to one target unless your pointing your camera directly at them and/or using your WASD towards them. But, it's very easy to get the hang of it" so it's not much of a negative once you understand how it works.

Your Aura meter is your health pool. You can take damage until its depleted and a little bit more until you collapse completely. Stop taking damage for awhile and you'll regen it automatically. Easy enough

hoursPlayed: etc. Seemed a little more exploitable on Yang than the others. Sometimes a little too exploitable to be called broken.\n\nThe experience is my biggest pet peeve about the game. Whoever last hits

gets the experience. Doesn't matter if I've been bashing away at very tough monster - another player can swoop in with an ability to swipe the experience. This leads to a bit of a sour and competitive experience if you're trying to achieve level 10.

REPLAYABILITY:
So far

votesTotal: and want to unlock every talent for every character while enjoying the hack and slash RWBY style

it's a toss-up. If you're looking for a quick hack and slash while playing with your favorite RWBY character and don't mind the price point - pick it up. If you'd rather wait for more content than just a single campaign that lasts an hour at most - hold off.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes this game is in early access, but it is still extremely fun to play. Here are a few things I would like to say about it.

Let's start with the positive stuff:
-the game looks great, character models are pretty much identical to the ones in the show
-having the music from the show play during fights is really cool
-combat is tons of fun, each character plays differently with its unique special moves.

What I would like to see improved/ added to the game:
-there were a few graphical glitches or times where my character would glitch through textures
-dialogue subtitles sometimes didn't load properly
-many of the fights lacked the epic soundtrack from the show
-it would be nice to add button mapping
-I would really love to see more characters from the show be added to the game.

All in all, this is tons of fun to play. Of course, the game development isn't complete so there is only one chapter to play, and you may encounter a few glitches here and there. Do I recommend it in this stage of development? Yes, not just because I am a RWBY fan, but because the game is not broken like many other early access titles out there, and because the developpers will add more content in the future. Besides, they said the price would go up as more features are added, so get it now and pay less than if you wait!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As everyone has already stated, this is an Early Access title. Be that as it may, this is a very GOOD Early Access title. Rooster Teeth has done an excellent job bringing the RWBY girls to the game world. If you like the show, get in on this at the ground level and show your support. For Monty!

What I liked:
>Combat is fluid and easy to pick up on
>Animation and voices all match the source material
>Each character has their own feel and abilities

What I'd like to see done:
>More combo attacks and finishers. Make em nice and flashy!
>2, 3 or even 4 person combos. Think Dual and Triple Techs from Chrono Trigger
>Hopefully there will be LOTS of levels to cut swathes through
>Add a tutorial mode? Won't need too much as it's fairly straightforward
>Add a lock-on feature. It's not hard to target an enemy but it would make the camera behave better

Please fix:
>Needs better audio control. Right now you can only change the music and voice volume. SFX volume is too high but I got around it using the volume mixer via Windows
>Animations are still slidey and going down hills needs fixed too

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really good base for what could eventually be one of my favorite games ever.  While I also would've really liked a turn-based RPG approach, a hack n slash is definitely the best way to transition RWBY into a video game.

Characters -

The characters themselves need to be worked on a lot more. They have a bit of a samey feel from one another, and it's not like you don't have a lot of things you could do for each of them to make them unique from one another. The upgrade tree could definitely go more in-depth and allow you to truly customize the way you play. Ranging from max aura, aura recharge, movement speed, attack speed, max special meter, increased special meter gain, and more. I really like what they're currently doing with upgrading your special abilities, they just need to branch out a bit. I also think they should add more special abilities per character, and allow you to pick 3 of them at any time.

Also, they really need to add more dialogue. The story is pretty much nonexistent in this game, as it is currently, it just seems like its nothing but random training assignments from various mentors from Beacon with very minimal communication between the actual team members.

Once they've gotten team RWBY down, all nice and polished, they should definitely add more teams! We all know people want to see JNPR. Not really sure how they would exactly handle this. Perhaps allow the host of a lobby to select what team will be used for the current map? But that's looking a bit too far right now, let's focus on getting RWBY completely done, in my opinion.

Levels -

The game so far is really, really barebones and doesn't justify the 15$ price tag. There's just not much here. If you're buying your way into this at its current state, you should be doing it solely to provide feedback. There's a handful of levels to play through, most in which consist of defense sections with the exception of the last one, which is a modified payload mode. It definitely needs more variety from that standpoint. Having to defend every 5 minutes in each level is pretty tedious, and there's so many things you could do in exchange. Don't get me wrong, a few defense sections are okay. But they should be among a bunch of other gamemodes in order to mix things up to keep the player interested. Don't be afraid to become inspired by other games such as Warframe and TF2 in order to come up with new possible ways to make levels vary. It would be really cool to just have a level where your goal is to collect hidden artifacts, much like the beginning of Volume 1, and you have to fight the Crow and Scorpion Grimms.

It would be absolutely insane if they allowed us to do 8 player co-op, where two teams of 4 have to complete objectives in different parts of the map. Much like what went on during the first training session in RWBY Volume 1.

At the end, it is a really good base for what could become a great game. It is very, very far from it right now. I recommend it solely to people who want to provide feedback and help the game grow. But if you want your totally epic RWBY game that's finished, you'll have to wait a while for this game to make more progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For Early Access -game this game still provides you with amazing gameplay style and visuals. Since purchase I have played this game every day and still I'm learning more from it. The graphics in this game are amazing. The game also is very balanced. For example if one out of four people leaves, the game lowers the difficulty.

Graphics are really high in this game and it's suprising for an indie game. If you're laptop or other low end PC user, don't worry. You can still play this game on ''potato quality'' and it still looks really nice.

Voice acting in this game is really good. It's really great to here your idols to give you tips or comment on your actions. Blake's voice acting though is really dull and quiet. I would like to hear her to say longer sentences and be louder. Otherwise the voice acting is pure gold.

Gameplay in this game is really good. The camera isn't annoying like in most of these kinda games and open areas gives more time to react on enemys' attacks. Exploring in this game is really fun and collectibles are really cool idea. Exp:s in crates are little annoying though. Only one player can get them and it breaks the coop gameplay. In my opinion they sholud be shared with a whole team.

So far there are only 4 playable characters. Don't worry if your favourite character is already taken. You can pick the same character as someone else has already taken. For example I always pick  Weiss and it would be pretty annoying if I couldn't be her.

So, if you're big fan of RWBY or Rooster Teeth itself, I would recommend giving it a try!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

MAY 8TH UPDATE: Removed positive feedback about the models, removed negative feedback about movement and gameplay issues. Removed negative point about lack of single player and tutorial. All in all nothing has improved that much and they've made bad choices about the new character models.

So, main immediate issues of the game:
* No player progression system, no customization, etc. Characters do level up in self-contained games, but you retain nothing once the game is done.
* Despite being a cooperative game, in-game experience isn't shared by the team, encouraging players to screw each other over to level faster.
* Dreadful lack of different enemy types.
* Can't remap controls.
* Can't customize graphics options thoroughly.
* Hacking through hordes of enemies doesn't feel satisfying. There's not enough enemies, and enemies have a bit too much health, and tear you to shreds too fast. Feels nothing like the trailer!
* Fair amount of bugs, especially graphical.
* The models of the game, originally faithful to the show, now look ugly as sin, generic anime doll models that are actually freaky to look at. This game no longer looks like a RWBY game, it looks like a generic anime action game with a low budget.

But, hey, upsides:
* Is early access, so one can expect huge additions to the game.
* The base skeleton of the game is pretty solid.
* Very responsive controls, although undocumented.

For the moment! Probably not worth its full price tag. It's fun for what it is, but not 15$ fun. It's a fun 4-player hack and slash, and you should look forward to what it will look like in a few months if they actually start adding stuff, fixing issues, etc., but at the moment it's a bit lackluster. This game more than most Early Access titles really IS Early Access quality.

This review will be updated when and if the game shapes up!

Just to make it clear: I don't regret the purchase. I really do look forward to this being a full game. In the meantime though I can't recommend buying it without first acknowledging its downfalls and being sure you want it.

And sorry, but no, I don't think it's Early Access
date: you can't judge the game yet!" really flies. People are being asked to pay for it right now
hoursPlayed: so it's important that people know what they're paying for right now."

I have been extremely impressed with the quality of a game coming from a company that got its start making Halo machinimas (before the mainstream).

There are several points I would like to note for this review.

+Impressively smooth gameplay and engine
+Gameplay - feels like a hybrid of Kingdom Hearts and Dynasty Warriors (which hold a close place to my heart). The game provides the satisfaction of being able to simply mow down crowds of enemies while mainting a somewhat complex combo system. A balance of these perfectly defines a hack and slash experiecne.
+Great representation of original material - If you are playing this, odds are that you have already watched the show. If you haven't watched the show, then go watch.

Overall, this game has immensive potential, it is still early in development so a 8/10 is fitting given the lack of other features.

I can't wait to see how this game shapes up.

Happy Hunting Huntsmen and Huntresses.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Last updated: 04 December 2015
This, my friend, is early access. As much as I want to give this game a recommendation, I cannot. Not yet. I'm definitely excited for the final product of this game, but it needs some work.

Cons:
- Animations are still very choppy
- Subtitles struggle to keep up with the longer speeches in the game
- Your character progress does not save
- Are we not sharing exp? Did that Blake just KS for exp?!
- If you’re not a RWBY fan, you’ll probably have no idea what is going on, story-wise (this may be a pro for some people)
- The results screen after every map looks like I’m playing a SNES game (again, this may be a pro for some people)

Pros:
- It’s a RWBY game.
- I love the work put into the voices so far.
- Characters seem to stay true to the franchise
- the combat will be very enjoyable (once the animations are smoothed out, maybe additional enemies…)

Things that would be nice to have:
- Add a button to see the status of the party (levels, health, etc)?
- Perhaps add items/equipment for characters to equip?
- Customizable controls?

As of 04 December 2015, the only people who should be buying this game IMO are 1) RWBY fans who wish to aid the developers with feedback, and 2) people who like playing early access games in general to give feedback.
In its current state, it’s a $5 early access game, not $15.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to preface this saying I enjoy RWBY.

The quality of the current game is decent, but it's frustrating to see that said quality has deteriorated since the April Combat Revision patch.

This review is current as of 6/3, the Butter and Butter Patch.

What's good
The gameplay is really fun. It's a hack-and-slash game, so if you have any experience playing a Dynasty Warriors type game, you'll feel right at home here. The game is as competitive as it is co-operative, and attacks feel satisfying to produce. The game has no difficulty levels. Youre difficulty varies from easy / medium by yourself, and medium / hard with other people.
What got fixed
They added a chapter select option, something which was needed for a long time.
Some graphics options such as SSAO and bloom have been added.
What's not so good
TL;DR for this bullet point: The models / textures could use some work. The models / shaders as of the current update are not representative of what the characters in the show look like. They seemed to have deteriorated from the show's quality for the purpose of optimization, but the design choice alienates higher end users that can render the show's models.
The main issue is the faces, but also extends to a reduced level of detail on the character models since the April Combat Revision patch.

-     Ruby's skirt before the patch was a meandering, flowing skirt with ruffles underneath it. The new model gives Ruby's skirt a significantly more blocky and triangular appearance. The fluffy undercoat is now a blocky, solid model.
-     Weiss's bolero's collar is now straight, compared to how it had ruffles before the update.
-     Blake is missing the ruffles on her vest.
-     The eye shape as well as the eyelashes of the characters has definitely been changed.

This is actually a major factor: If you play an anime game, you have some expectation it looks like the show it represents. Naruto games looks like Naruto anime. JoJo games looks like the JoJo anime. You get rid of that, you lose a lot of the appeal.
The sound design could use some work. This also has deteriorated since the April Combat Revision patch.
Little in the way of graphic options besides SSAO and bloom. You can control the overall level of detail, but the game always renders shadows and you have little control tweaking certain aspects of rendering feature-by-feature.
Progression is limited; level is capped at 10. While not a big deal if you use the chapter select, a full playthrough will allow you to reach the level cap pretty easily, which isn't a good thing.
Content is a little short for the current price point. A playthrough will take anywhere from only 90 minutes to 2 hours.
I won't say I hate this game. I really want this game to be better. But for now, I have to give this game a negative review until the devs improve the quality of the game so its in line with what fans would want out of a game about the show they love.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lately, after playing quite a few hours and enjoying the game, I looked through reviews to see what others thought and found a number of things from the negative sections that seemed a bit off to me. While some people gave valid points to issues in it, I think there are several things that people complain about that aren't really all that valid, and have decided to make my own review because of it. Lets get to the bad stuff first.

Cons:
- Subtitles need some work
- No difficulty adjustment for replaying levels
- A few graphical and audio glitches here and there
- Some work needed on blocking off areas you aren't supposed to be in

These were the main things that come to mind for me. Some people have listed other things that I quite frankly don't think need to be on the list. First one is the price tag. Is the game in it's currents state worth $15? No, but it's early access. I feel like people see early access and think of something like Day Z. That game in it's current state is worth what is charged to most people. Problem is that game has been in early access for years. There are other games like it that are at the end of the early access games, and some that just stay there but are pretty much done but use it to say that they periodically add large content patches like Minecraft does. This game, as of the time of this review, has just hit early access, and RT is fully taking advantage of the title. This game is far from a finished product and you slapping down the $15 is kinda like a donation with benefits really. You give them money so they can keep making the game, they give you access to it while it's in developement and can give feedback. If you want a polished, complete game worth $15, don't get it. If you want to support the concept and idea of the game, or RT in general, pick it up. There are also complaints about combat being too repetative, but I feel like unlocking the challange perks and remebering the blast attacks adds more than people give it credit for. More variation is not something I would be opposed to, but at this point I don't think the combat deserves such a bad rap from people. Also, people don't seem to like levels not carrying over. The thing is, with this type of game that just wouldn't work. If I hit level ten then rerun from the beginning, I'm gonna be destroying everything no problem. Add that to the fact that I wouldn't be able to get anymore perks since I'm at the level cap and couldn't expiriment with new skills, and you see that it just doesn't work. As long as they find a good way to keep levels going when they add more levels and content, this system works just fine. Lastly, I've seen complaints that swarms of enemies keep you from combing too easily with attacks that can't be intterupted. Personally, I havn't had a problem with this after my first playthrough. I won't go into details as this is long enough already, but teamates are there for a reason and so are evades. Use them right and you should be fine.

Now to the good things.
Pros:
- Well voice acted
- Great art design and character models
- Interesting abilities and a nice leveling system
- Characters keep their personalities from the show
- Alternate paths and challanges give some level of replayability.
- Interesting enemies with variation

I can't say much to the plot since it isn't very developed so far, but I think it looks good for now. We won't realy know until more comes out. Hopefully this sheds some light on the game for everyone, along with why some of the cons really aren't cons.

Final verdict, get it if you like the idea of the game and want to support it or RT, as it is fun so far and has great groundwork, but don't expect a huge amount of content until later in development. Happy hunting!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

!!! UPDATE 1 AND 2 REVIEW !!!

This game is great. If you are a fan of RWBY I highly reccomend you pick this up, if not, maybe take a pass. Even in early access it is quite good. The sights and sounds match the show and it really feels like the world of remnant. For those wondering there is about 12 hours of gameplay. It's about 3 hours per character to unlock all challenges. There are a few issues with the game such as animation errors,  being able to go outside the map in a few places, and Weiss being able to get her third level upgrade for her ranged attack without getting the second prior but those will probably be ironed out when the full game is released. There's also a few glitches I hope they don't patch such as the burning Yang glitch. In the end it is a really fun game and experience.

!!! UPDATE 3 REVIEW !!!
The new update makes a lot of changes, some good and some meh. The graphics look amazing as every and the new combat feel so much smoother. I like how they added a offline mode as well. I do have some issues though. This new camera is really strange to me, it keeps rotating when I try to attack and that isn't something I like. Also I got used to the new ultimate system but I much prefer the old special system. Two of the old specials have been moved into combo moves which is okay but I still prefer special. They also patched some glitches but I miss going outside the map :P (also rip the burning Yang glitch....you will always be my fave ;_;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So normally I don't really write reviews, but this is one of those times where I feel like I should.

RWBY: Grimm Eclipse is a pretty freaking amazing game for being in Early Access. I have followed this game since its inception and it has not let me down yet. GE (Grimm Eclipse) is a hack and slash game which can be played with upto four people. The basis of GE, RWBY, is an animated show released by RoosterTeeth, and this game shows how amazing that company can be.

The story is still pretty bare bones, but is constantly being added to as the updates roll out. However, the story in GE is seperate from RWBY, from Volume 2 of the show on. This is great as it allows the devs to have fun with the IP they got.

The gameplay, where do i begin, is freaking awesome. Think Metal Gear Rising: Revengance with 4 highschool girls in a world where the normal rules of physics are thrown out of the window. Each character has their own play style, and moves to complement said style. Personally I play as Weiss Schnee. She is more of the mage character, as she is more support and area based with her moves than the rest of her team. While i do mainly play as Weiss, i have unlocked all the special skills for every character. While it can take some time if you do it on your own, playing with others, whether its friends or random people, is much more enjoyable and will net you more kills.

Graphically it looks breath taking. This game is built in unity, so be prepared for bright colours and amazing models. There are a few different graphical settings: Potato, for if you dont have the best PC/Laptop, Normal, and Ultra, which is what i run. There is no V-Sync, however with the right settings it will run at a buttery smooth 60FPS.

All in all this game is really enjoyable and if you have the money, give it a go, you will not regret it!

I rate this game a 9.5/10, but keep in mind this is still an early access game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR- I am a big fan of the RWBY video series. I find this game is worth what I paid for it as I've throughly enjoyed the hours I've played it. While it does have flaws they're easy to over look as it's fresh release early access and I've spent more money on worse games than this. From what I see there is a solid ground work laid for the Developer to build a great game off of as it comes out of EARLY ACCESS. Worth it IMO.

Long Version- I am a fan of RWBY, while I love the series I'll be as honest as I can about the games short comings. I've spent almost 9 hours so far playing this game, and I'm still enjoying it.

The game is early access, this is sometimes brutally apparent on some of the graphical/sound glitches  you will come across (there have been far fewer visual/sound glitches since the first patch). It also only has two levels you can currently play. The character customization (skill tree) is very basic but the system is there to be built upon. So far the game has not crashed and I've been running it on max settings. I've had no problems jumping into online games or having other people jumping into my online games. While it's not really a single player option you can play solo by creating your own lobby and setting it to friends only while you're in offline" mode
date: but at this point in time it's the same as multiplayer. There are no character saves
recommended:
so every time you start a new game you have to progress from character Level 1. The good news is kills and unlocked skills DO stay when you make new characters so you don't have to struggle like hell. I would like to think that Rooster Teeth will finish polishing this game until is shines like the show it's based on.


PRO list:

•Voice acting has real voice actors.  (go team RWBY!)

•3 days after early release they fixed the sound glitches
hoursPlayed:
no more bleeding ears!
•Also fixed the bugs where soundFX would cancel out voices.

•Character personas are like their series counterparts

•Visually appealing environments even though it is early access.

•Minor (very minor

like I've only seen one on each zone) route changes on maps. You're not always running down the same paths. (I can only hope this might one day have some randomization to locations like Mountain Glen.)

•Super easy controls for mindless smash and bash fun. I've used Keyboard and Xbox controllers happily.

•Quick match is actually quick
helpfulPercent:
I've never spent more than 10 seconds before being connected to a game.

CON list:

•Invisible walls

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This update killed the game for me. I can't recommend this anymore.
This game used to be fun to play and beautiful to look at, ran really smoothly, and for an early access game was pretty stable.
But now, the models that used to be almost 1:1 exact to their models from the show are now replaced these cheap knockoffs. The update runs at some really bad framerates even on the lowest settings. The lighting can get really obnoxious, the biggest offender being at the end Forever Fall part two, where near the end of the level after defeating a wave of grimm you are greeted by THIS GIANT SUN IN YOUR FACE. When you get to that part for the love of god TURN DOWN THE BRIGHTNESS ON YOUR SCREEN, YOU WILL THANK ME LATER. Ontop of that, there are parts of some levels that you can now fall through the floor, or cause the stage to CLIP THROUGH ITSELF. None of this was a problem in the previous update.
They've also made attacks weaker, making Grimm take longer to kill. What was once a fun gameplay style turns into a chore when waves now take FOREVER to finish.
The enjoyment factor for this game has gone down TREMENDOUSLY. If this is the direction this game is going in, then count me out. I'm done. I used to be hyped for a RWBY game was hoping it would eventually come to consoles so I can get some of my friends in on this too. But as it stands now, I can't recommend this.
I hope the dev team proves me wrong with future updates. I backed up the previous update and now I'm reverting back to it. So I can remember the fun times this game used to be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played 5 Hours in the Beta back for sponsers, and I absolutely love the RWBY series.
Really fun game and has a lot of potential to grow!

Quick Specs
I am running a GTX 980, 16 GB of Ram, 4.2ghz processor, all on SSD

Pros:
+Very smooth combat
+Custom voice acting for the game is a nice touch
+Level up system is nice and desciptive enough to know what you get when you choose a specific perk
+Multiplayer connection is smooth with little rubber banding
+MOST areas on the map you wont find youself being able to clip into the outside world
+No crashes or frame rate issues
+ The 4 girls for the most part are equally as good (my prefrence was Ruby) but the other three are still good.

Cons:
-Menu is a little buggy in the actual game (pressing esc), by that I mean you sometimes can't select options with your mouse and you have to still play around with it to get it to work.
-You can get out of the map pretty easily in some parts just as long as you know where to go, no I wont tell you where
-Running animation is very buggy at times
-Wish there was an option for local LAN, it is a bit old school but with gamming laptops on a rising trend if my friends got  this game and came over to my place it would be nice to play using just my netowrk to minimalize any type of connection lag.
-I can get into Fallout 4 significantly faster on my computer then getting into RWBY: GE, start up takes some time for some odd reason.
-Can not re-map my controlls, I really have no reason too but other people for a fact will want to.

Nit Picky Section (As I play the game more I will add any little things here)
-No SFX scroll for sound, so I cant make the gun shots and scyth slices quiter
-No tutorial so for newer players your just going to have to figure everything out, the help section does contain controls so that is a bonous
-Wish I had to option to voice communicate not just text

The game is still so new it is very hard to nit-pick every fine detail and judge it. Since it is an early access beta it deserves a bit of an handicap; however, I will say this, for an early access beta, this is one of the best ones I have played in terms of the gaming running fluidly even in its early stages.
Good Job RT games and I wish you the best of luck in doing this game right :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not much to say except that if you like hack-n-slash games, then you should definitely pick this game up.  If you are a fan of the show AND like the game genre, then it is a must have.

The gameplay feels pretty solid, typical weak/strong attack combos, although a bit simplified and clunky-ish at the moment there is always more room to improve.  Currently there is only one campaign with 4 stages, which takes about 30-45 minutes to complete, so there isn't much in the content department as of now.

Also, there isn't much variety in enemy types as of now, but will definitely expand for sure.

*edit 1-15-16* I forgot to add, one gripe i have with this game currently is the lack of offline (no internet required) play. you have to be connected to the internet to play any game.

This may be a turn off to some because not everyone has a good internet connection to play or they live in areas with no service at all (but have to go elsewhere for internet). I would also like to mention that during a game if you disconnect you get kicked from the game and have to start a new game back at level 1 again.

I do hope the devs will implement an offline feature in the future, i do not see any harm in this. This game feels like it should be able to play offline, due to the kind of game it is.

Overall, besides the very minor graphical glitches, my experience has been a very positive one and I feel this game will be one of the best games to own in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think the first thing that needs to be said is that while I do, in fact, recommend this game, I recommend it under the condition that it receives polish appropriate to a series as impactful and immensely popular as RWBY.

So far, Grimm Eclipse is like a flash project. Its very basic and the 'campaign' can be completed in less than an hour. What keeps it standing so far is the intriguing ways that it divides the skills of Team RWBY into different trees that all manage to feel cohesive and part of the RWBY universe.

The visuals are actually fairly nice, but the voice acting is flat and disappointing. They have some intersting mechanics that make me feel like there is more this game has to offer in the future. I do, however, have to strictly recommend this game only to die-hard fans. I don't regret the purchase myself, despite the current product being a bit underwhelming. I look forward to seeing what will happen with it in the future. I'm sure it goes without saying that RWBY fans have high expectations of a faithful adaptation of the late Oum's work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes I know it’s in early access but my main problem with the game at its current state is... Its feel more of a mix between a demo to a 5$ game worth, then a 15$ early access to me. I mean when I play games that 15$ like don’t starve, legend of korra and octodad which has more hours you can put into it then this game, I feel it’s a bit unfair atm.

Also keep in mind, half of the positive reviews are the fandom speaking, not the gamer, if this was a re-skin of a different series and made by different devs, especially they weren't so popular and love by, this game would had the real honest reviews of  a mostly negative or mix reviews(especially since this game is no different from the poorly done hack and slash movie license  games like Thor and Green lantern from 2011) so if you a huge RWBY fan and not much a general gamer this game for you but if you're a general gamer that cares about the work and content it provides, then don't bother with this game until it's out of early access so in its Current state is a 3/10 as of now...But anyway let’s get down to the pros and cons.

Pros

- Its RWBY, I never watch the anime or have no plan to but I actually respect the community and even for the game it’s not that bad.

-I actually love the leveling system and skill tab system they have, seem pretty balanced and far off great.

- Graphics is really beautiful for an anime game, play on ultra-high settings and the bloom effect in the background is just beautiful.

-voice acting is pretty neat and look like they put forth effort into it.

Cons

-Only 4 levels, it took me just an hour to beat, even if it’s in early access, I don’t find this acceptable imo

-No combos in it, just hit left click  as your main attacks and right click as your Alt-Attack and your 123 keys, congratulation, you know how to master all the characters.

-Enemy’s feel like they’re missing attacks animation’s and a bit too easy imo, even if your health bar about to go to zero, you can just run around and in 3 seconds, your health bar is full again, hopefully they can change that or else the game is to easy and un-fit.

-They say is like a dynasty warriors and left 4 dead mix into it, but feels more like  dungeon defenders and Anarchy Reigns cause of the lack of combos and all the mission is just defending machines and areas. I mean imo if it’s to be a mix of left for dead and dynasty warriors, I suspect  more combos, capturing areas and bases and huge waves of enemies to get over thousands of kills and more areas to explore and less invisible walls.

- No save progression and or anything to keep your character stats save, also the level cap is 10, at its state just repeat the game over and over again until they bring more content.

-And finally slow updates and content been coming, been 3 months since the game posted as of the day I edit this review and barely any content and father more  it seem half other RWBY fandom think this is ok, which is not of course.

I kind of saw this coming when the game was 1st on green light and I knew it wasn’t’ going to be all that great, but before you post any negatives comments or give me a thumbs down, I’m actually impress with it so far and think rooster teeth doing great, just at the current state I can’t give it a thumbs up and how the community being to positive" with this game
date: maybe when it feels like 15$ or more then it is right now. I’ll give it a thumbs up. I also only brought the game for friend reason and have no interest to seeing the anime."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has got to be one of the most fun, well optimized and addictive games I've ever played! Whenever you think you've gotten bored, you're truly not!

Before reading please understand that I am a very hardcore fan of Rooster Teeth's RWBY animated series though my feedback is presented after playing the game's unfinished 1st campaign with two different playthroughs.

You see a beautiful main menu screen upon opening this game that entails the bright and graphically handsome visuals of Emerald Forest, a slowly/mildly turning camera around the mis-én-scene. You have three options (I believe); PLAY, SETTINGS and EXIT (QUIT).

Under the settings you will find that you can choose between potato (yes potato), standard (neutral graphical settings, not too high but not too potato either) :-) and lastly ultra, which maxes out everything and gives you a bloom effect. Sadly there is no advanced graphical setting at this current time however it is acceptable seeing that this is at its pre-alpha (or alpha) stage. If you are a user who owns a beast (or even fairly decent) computer, chances are you are very capable of running it at ultra, the game has little recommended requirements, I get a SOLID 60 fps (hell, it even goes to 61 at times!)

You will very rarely experience the occasional fps spike when appearing in a large crowd of Grimm, though it is expected after all! Additionally, you will also SOMETIMES see your character's running animation freeze for a few miliseconds when advancing along a steep path and/or bumpy path.

I first started this game with no other than Weiss Schnee (Yep, not Ruby! Weiss-o serious?). I got the YANG of this game after a good few minutes of gameplay and if I may say so myself, it is pretty great in comparison to other early access Steam games at a very early alpha stage.

If you are looking to buy this, please understand that the developers are doing their best so expect faults! They gave this beauty to us at an alpha stage to enjoy as they continue to create more content. I asked a game developer and he said they're hoping to update the game monthly assuming progress is going swell.

Finally, at this present time there is only one campaign and it is incomplete. You will experience around a couple hours worth of gameplay to rack up (average imo).

TL;DR -

If you want to support Roosterteeth's RWBY Game Team then please buy this game, it is HEAPS of fun with friends! Rate: 9/10 (alpha rating).

+ PROS +

+ It's A FREAKING RWBY GAME!
+ RWBY cast voice actors
+ Yang puns
+ GOOO TEAM RWBY!
+ Addictive and fun
+ Great gameplay for early alpha game
+ No bugs with monsters that I've seen (Grimm)
+ 4 player coop is well optimized
+ Performance is a solid 7-8/10

- CONS -

- Occasional momentary FPS spikes (for me it went down from 60 to 38-41 but immediately shot back up to a solid 60)
- Can't move your camera up higher than average camera height
- Not enough usage of RWBY music ( + not loud enough)
- You don't keep your level and skills after leaving your game session and going into another one
- Yang doesn't make noises when she fights (not that I can hear)
- Semblances aren't 100% complete for each character

Can't think of any more cons, though the ones I've listed already are easily fixable as the developers release updates as time goes by. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok im going to start by saying that this is a very new game. Early Access New.

The Base Premis is there, and for what it is its great.

I bought the game today and have played through the content availiable, from what I can take from the experiance is that the game has so much potential. If the programmers stick to It I am sure this will be a success on the lines of Left for Dead.

As a fan of RWBY I can say that the team synergy is there, your constantly diving into groups of mobs on top of your team mates, when there down you instantly look to revive them. You know what your getting yourself into and that is a hack and slash game that is in the style of the RWBY world that is in its early stages.

The Game is not all sunshine and rainbows, do not expect to start this and have saved character builds, customisation or even keeping your level.

However we need to remember that in its stage we are still TESTING the game, there will be bugs (none that I have seen) there will be features that you want, if you do not support the product we will not get them.

I will recommed this game, I will recommend it not for the future alone, but the state its in now. Play It, Enjoy It and Take on the Role of Team RWBY!

Thanks for reading! n.n

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy this game only if you really like the series and really desperate for more RWBY because at this current state, this game is lacking in everything. Thats my short review of RWBY. now for the longer review..

First thing first, since this is a hack and slash action game the combat need to be really good. Soo, how is RWBY: Grimm Eclipse combat ? It got a lot of potential, but right now there isn't anything that you can do when encountering enemies except to press the dodge button when they about to attack and then press the attack button 8 times to do that 8 hit combo. There isn't any combining 2 to 3 of different attack button to combo your attack, just 1 button for attack, one button for dodge, and occasionally use the skill button to do 1 of the 3 skill available, long range skill, AoE skill to hit all the enemies around you, and another AoE skill that hit all the enemies in front of you. I have to admit its pretty awesome  when you keep the combo going by keep hitting the enemies, but the overall combat mechanic at this current state ? Its not really that great.

The leveling system in this game is per match basis, so you didn't carry your level when you change the map, kinda like DotA 2 as the developer said. But, how is the leveling so far ? There isn't anything interesting in it, you didn't even feel that great when you level up since you didn't earn a new combo or anything, you only can choose what essentially a damage buff to all your existing skill, a health buff, a regeneration buff, and all other sort of other buff. That didn't make you feel more powerful then before. They really need to improve this if they want to make a great game, make it so that you learn new combo or add a new skill that you can use or something.

The graphics itself its really good, it really capture the series aesthetic even though its natural for them to do that since the company that make the cartoon animation is the same as the company that make the game, they could just pulled the guy/gal that draw and make the cartoon animation to make the game animation. Well i have to point out that i have suffer a one second random freeze during my playthrough, even though my laptop isn't that great but it can run both Fallout 4 and GTA V, i'm sure it should be able to run this without any hiccup.

Cons-Artstyle for characters became nothing like the show's in the last update

Music (and all sound settings) is at default on max, which is too low for me

Subtitles aren't accurate at parts (missing whole sentences/paragraphs)

The voices are too quiet

Very basic a.i that ignores obstacles (grimm can get stuck on stuff for easier kills)

Can be beat in under 2 hours (main campaign which is majority of content)

Only 4 playable characters (all of team rwby excluding zwei) (more are planned and jnpr is confirmed)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love RWBY but I am not a big fan of Hack and Slash games. Despite that, I fell in love with this game. It captures the spirit of the show very well. reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a beta that just hit the shelves of Mid-December 2015, based on an animated series that isn't too far yet, this game is really good if your a fan of the Animated series RWBY.  The controls are fairly responsive and has a variety of attacks along with great character models and voice acting.  The game looks very good! You can't expect them to make it look realistic, it would ruin the Animeish feel.  There is currently a few bugs, but that is to be expected from an early access game.  The bugs don't even harm the gameplay.  Currently, if you're not too much of a fan of the RWBY series, $15 is a bit steep, but if you really like the Animated series and want to contribute, go ahead! It's a really nice game!

Pros:
-Great animations
-Voice acting is good
-Character models
-Feels like the Anime
-Fun
-High Replayability
-Great if you have friends that also own it
-Multiplayer is great
-Monters are good
-Game Looks good overall

Cons:
-Currently has a short storyline
-Has some bugs
-Needs to be optimised a little (You really shouldn't need a gtx 650 ti as a reccomended card)
-Subtitles need a little work
-Needs a way to adjust the difficulty

9/10 <- First impression.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying, I don't recommend this RIGHT NOW. For reasons I'll state below.

First off, I understand it's in Early Access and there will be improvements, if the improvements are good then I'll happily change my rating.

Cons:
No lock on?
This game is incredibly inconsistent with what locks on, and what doesn't. I've had attacks from weiss hit monsters at point blank and the next one right after flies right over and hits nothing. And other times,  I've had moves miss someone in front of me, but then that same move a minute later will do a 90 degree turn and hit someone next to me.

The sound design is atrocious, the voice acting is obviously fine at the moment, but the sound effects, hit sounds, falling, aura recharge(Oh dear lord RIP headphone users) are all terrible, there's so much audible clutter. The characters grunt all the time, the weapon hit sounds all sound the same and lack any real distinction. And the aura recharge will actually blow out your ears if you're not careful with the volume. And also, did I mention there's no SFX slider in options? I checked.

Gameplay
Characters all play the same, it's left click spam to win. They have minor variation in skills and hitboxes for those skills. But while playing them, I've found there's no real big distinction in gameplay. All monsters are extremely easy and brainless to fight, I feel like I'm playing Dynasty warriors but they just gave the enemies more health, so imagine the fun of mowing down enemies in dynasty warriors, without the fun, you just slowly grind through a giant mob. And the challenge" is when they all gang up on you

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

This game is a very fun experience to play through.  It is still in early development and it shows, but with time this game can really shine and become something amazing.

**PLEASE NOTE:  I obtained this game as a gift and the game is in Early-Access at the time of review.  I try to be middle of the ground when reviewing but this still must be noted**

Gameplay
Over View
GRIMM ECLIPSE is a third person hack and slash" game (as seen by the tags) that uses the Rooster Teeth RWBY franchise.  Players have the ability to choose who to play as between the four protagonists of the series:  Ruby
hoursPlayed: and Blake.  In a cooperative (or solo) group the players battle through hordes and waves of enemies.  As somebody kills enemies they obtain experience points that level players up; at each level an ability point is gained.  This point can be spent to improve the abilities of the chosen character or saved for more expensive upgrades (the most costing 2 points).\n\nOne flaw with the gameplay is that it gets repetative after a few hours.  It is a fun
voteText: a truely fast paced game
helpfulPercent:
but once the charm of it fades then the game begins to feel the same...

Difficulty
The difficulty of RWBY GRIMM ECLIPSE was slightly disappointing.  Traditionally "hack and slash" games are not very difficult so it isn't a huge deal.  Players can utilize the ranged attacks and strong attacks to blow through most enemies that the game throws at the player.  The upgrade system makes it feel like players are significantly stronger then every enemy at times while other times it feels like you are a level 1 again.  The game has a lack of difficulty settings that creates a disconnect for people who have experience with these types of games.  If a difficulty setting could be added then the game would be more appealing for both casual and players looking for a challenge.


Game Settings
This game as very few adjustable settings for game customization.  The video settings are very lacking in their options
votesHelpful: there is a fullscreen button
votesTotal: a resolution option (with 3-4 resolutions)
votesFunny: and a single graphical adjuster.  This isn't a big deal as the game isn't terribly resource intensive
commentsCount:
but on lower end machines expect to play on "potato" settings on a tiny window (I mean one of the smallest I have ever seen). There is no master volume slider which can be disorienting if you want to lower every sound equally; not a big deal but is a slight inconvenience.


Performance
The performance of this game is what is to be expected from an early access game; some spots run perfectly while others produce an intense amount of lag.  During play play I would experience frame drops occasionally but only near certain spots (like near a single wall).  The nature of these lag spikes indicate that small parts of maps are not optimized well or have a lot of things to be rendered near them.  Generally my computer (containing a GTX 745
column16:
i7-4790) ran the game at frames above 50fps.

I have tested slightly with a 6 year old Dell Studio 15 laptop on the lowest resolution with potato graphics settings.  The game is playable frame rate wise but the small resolution causes the character to be left off screen at times.  It can still be enjoyable if you really want it to be...

Online play was pretty smooth with occasional jumps (to be expected from every game).  This was reassuring as it meant the game engine was well optimized for online play
column17:
a major piece of this game.


One last test system was a custom built computer with a GTX 980
column18: i7-4790K and the general framerates were good.  There was some bazar shuddering of the camera that wasn't traditional lag on this machine (my first mentioned machine experience the same thing from time to time
column19:
but not this severe).  I do not know what caused this skipping.

Art and Sound
RWBY:  GRIMM ECLIPSE really excels in its art style and sound design.  The game looks like the RWBY web-series
column20: it is nice to see a game that sticks close with the material it is given.  The graphics made me feel like I was enjoying another episode of the hit series
column21:
I was hoping for this and Rooster Teeth delivered.  The scenery can look beautiful so don't just blow through the game if you decide to buy!

From a sound standpoint the game sounds like it should.  It has a pretty good balance and it sounds like what you would expect.  The only complaint was no master sound slider as mentioned earlier.

Room To Grow
This game has a lot of room to grow but it is still an enjoyable experience.  I got through the current campaign in about an hour of game time.  This wasn't a bad thing as it is still early-access and a big update is scheduled to come out soon.  Unfortunately
column22:
this game automatically takes people back to the lobby after they get as far as the game allows and everybody loses their levels.  This was unfortunate as it felt like an hour wasted for progress sake.  I hope the final game supports a save of character feature so players don't lose their level 10 Chitty Chatty Yang Yang.

The last major complaint is how similar all the characters left.  Each of the four characters had a different cosmetic look to them but the way they feel is very similar.  Some characters might have different roles overall but at this point they all felt the same amount of "featherless".

Add content
column23: optimize the game more
column24:
and make the characters a little bit more distinguished and the game will be improved a ton!  In its current state I do recommend buying RWBY: GRIMM ECLIPSE if you have friends who are also going to play it.  If you are not a big fan of RWBY I still recommend it if you are a fan of hack and slash games and want to try something new.

NOTE:  Over time the price will increase as the game is updated so consider soon if you want to have a lower cost for a potentially higher benefit!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is looking like it will become a very good game in the future. However, as it is at the moment, it is simply not worth the asking price of £10.99. It's fun for a while, sure, but the combat is currently very repetitive and dull. You move from area to area killing Grimm that spawn around you and search around for XP drops. Occasionally you'll have to defend a point for X amount of waves... you get the picture. The actual gameplay is very reminescent of something like DMC or Bayonetta, although it is very barebones at the moment. There are promises of extra areas and new characters coming soon, and I'm sure in time we'll have a whole host of content to play around with, different game modes and characters, etc. Don't get me wrong, I like this game and the show it's based off a lot, it just isn't worth it at the moment unless you're a die-hard RWBY fan. Wait for extra content before buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FOREVER FALL UPDATE (3.6 Hours, 5/6/2016) -- What a great update!  There was a lot of content in this one.  Extended the multiplayer and singleplayer campaign to about an hour total now.  The visuals and animations are a LOT more polished, although I do kind of miss the Borderlands esque shader that gave it that more cartoony edge, for some reason its missing in my game and I don't know if thats intentional or not.  As far as the taunts go, it is great to finally have them, however each character only gets one taunt and it can get kind of repetative and annoying hearing the other teammates doing the same taunt 20 times in a row.  The new map is beautiful by the way.  And I really like the incorperation of the new enemies.  Keep up the great work RT!

ORIGINAL REVIEW (2.1 Hours, 5/5/2016) -- I love this game.  The combat is probably my favorite part... blending aspects of Kingdom Hearts and Dynasty Warriors.  The music is amazing, and the voice acting (though there isn't that much voice acting) is solid and engaging.  It's really cool how the gameplay runs like a Left 4 Dead combined with Kingdom Hearts.  Also, unlike most games nowadays there really aren't any bugs (at least none that I have encountered in my short gameplay so far).

I only have a few criticisms, and I'm assuming they will be fixed with the upcoming updates;  Content wise, at 2.1 hours I have already beaten the campaign" twice

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty good, but needs improvement before I give it a wholehearted reccomendation.

Let's start with my biggest complaint: NO CHARACTER/CLASS SYNERGY! None whatsoever. CLass synergy is afantastic way to make multiplayer more fun for everyone, as it stands there is really no reason to play omline unmless it's with friends. Character/Class sybergy could go a long way towards making this game a bit less repetitive, which brings us nicely into my second complaint with the game: it gets repetitive quickly. You only have two regular attacks and three special attacks, and there are no combos in the game, turning what looks like a fun hack-and-slash into a repetitive button masher, where you spam regular attacks to recharge your special attack meter, rinse and repeat ad nauseum. ANd since all the characters start out with all of their special attacks unlocked, there is never any real sense of player progression, as all of the upgrades you get are either passive modifiers to the attack, or to the player character.

The game also lacks an offline mode for single player, so if you want to play solo, then you will need to create a private lobby and join the game with just you in in it. And finally, the RWBY stuff almost feels like window dressing. None of the characters handle all that differently, all of them feel the same, and the idea of each character in the show having a unique semblance isnt used AT ALL, which is a collosal missed opportunity to have the characters feel different from each other.

All that being said, there are a lot of good pinttts about this game as well. RT seems to undeerstand that Early Access" doesn't mean "♥♥♥♥ out an unfinished

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bow before Rooster Teeth Games !! I would say Rooster Teeth Games - Nailed it!!!!! ^^

If you think of buying RWBY Grimm Eclipse keep in mind its an alpha! You get a game that is still in development, so don´t be sad when you right now only can do a part of the campaign! But that small part is fun if you run in a full group. I have played now 10Hrs+ and had only 1 issue so far. And that is pretty good for a alpha, the game runs smoth on my  PC and I don´t have the best Specs:
CPU i5
GPU Gainward GTX 320
RAM 8 MB


After playing for a while on Ultra-High-Resolution I feeling like I am part of the animation. The Voices are from the original cast and you can play for now only Ruby´s group. The fighting animation feels good and smooth . While fighting you level you character up and each level you can spent points into skill tree. The level design looks good and so does the sound. One thing that I like is that the character is not always talking to after I press a skill. I found that very annoying in other similar games.

You can enter a game that is already in progress or host your own game. You can play in group with up to 4 people, the more people join the difficulty the game gets. I people leave the game adjusts also. Whats pretty good because people keep leaving . If the Host is  leaving the game , the game continous !! Only thing that will happen is that someone else will be host and game resets to the last fullfield camapaign part. This is a good solution, since you dont have todo the whole game from the start.

It totally has the RWBY vibe and so far I enjoy it. Even if I do over and over the same part but I can still recommend the game. And again keep in mind - ALPHA !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love RWBY, as I'm sure most people here do, and I want to love this game. It has the show's visual style which is unsurprising giving how much the shows looks like a video game cutscene. In fact when my friend and I first watched the show, he got increasingly frustraighted that it WASN'T a game. Well now we have this work in progress, which is fun but very very shallow. In fact if it weren't for the attached fandom this game would be gettng torn apart and the developers would be leaking money. But since we've all wanted a RWBY game for years we're eating it up myself inculded. The gameplay is MOBA style....which literally means nothing to me. It's kinda like a beat em up with our four leading ladies playable ATM.

Things that rock
New voice lines
Adjusts difficulty on the fly as people join/leave
the powers look cool and each member of team RWBY has differnt unlockable ones

However in the only 40 min I played this game I got so bored of it so quickly. That's cause theres no variety in gameplay. you run through areas as Grim spawn around you or just ahead/behind kill them keep moving....every so often you run up and activate a control thing or a bridge then you defend the area for four waves (really basic gameplay concept)....and that's all there is just more and more of that. Combat is fun at first but you quickly learn theres not really any combos and only two basic attacks right now (the heavy attack button is coming). Theres no saving you just start at the start every time which i guess is good because you can 'Max level' in an hour, but it really bothered me.

The enemies are of course things we've seen our heros face in the show, and they look and act almost how they should my biggest complaint it the Bore the game says it charges and then is disorianted for a moment. So of course I'm thinking ok I've faced charging enemies you dodge then attack while stunned another very common gameplay element BUT THEY DIDN'T EVEN GET IT RIGHT. It stops charging and is ready to attack again like as soon as it stops. I'm serious like within 2 seconds it gives its little warning at does it again. It's practically impossible to get to it unless more then one person is playing. In fact I found that about alot of enemies there isn't really a way to take on a group of enemies alone but to hit a few get hit, kite them untill you heal then repeat.

It so strange that a show that seems to come from people so familar with games has made a game that seems unable to offer anything new or take any risks.

Rumor has it team JPNR is coming and that'll really add alot so are more levels, enemies and hopefully some  actually engaging gameplay. As it is its a fun game for fans for an hour but nothing else. If this were the days of Blockbuster and Rodgers video stores this game would be a rental at best.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it's finished, sure--but as of right now, it's really not worth the 15 dollar price tag. I got through all 4 of the levels within less than an hour, so that's a big minus.

The one thing that is amazing about it, is there didn't seem to be any issues at all with the online multiplayer, it was really smooth and worked nicely. Pretty damn surprising for early access.

The game basically has 4 levels of fighting minor enemies, and then defending a point via a horde mode type thing with waves and stuff. There's some monster variety, but not very much right now.

The combat is fun imo, but it feels a little barebones, but there isn't much to do but spam attacks with 3 abilities on the side. You can upgrade them, but not enough for it to really feel like it makes an enormous difference.

The visuals are all right, they're true to the show itself so, technically it's a 10/10. The 4 maps have variety to them visually, so that was nice. They are linear though, so that is kind of a bummer.

I enjoyed it overall, but it needs a lot more before it's worth the pricetag. I'm a big fan of RWBY, so here's to hoping it turns out awesome once it's completed!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, so I only played through the campaign about once or twice as of this review and given my first impressions of what I have played through was fairly impressive but at the same time it feels somewhat shallow. So despite enjoying my time with it, why do I not recommend RWBY: Grimm Eclipse as of now? The problem is that it's too shallow in depth to even consider the $15 purchase as of now. If you really think about it, what if it's not a RWBY game?

Well, what's good about the game? I would say its strongest point is how it remains faithful to the series with the overall environment and the voice acting being almost spot on with Blake's performance being a bit... off. The combat feels arcade-like and fast-paced much like the animation style to the show itself, but that's when I'm starting to run out of good things to say about this game.

Going back the combat, all of the characters feel exactly the same from one another with no distinct playstyle, just blindingly spamming left click until the enemy's health hits zero while occasionally using a special move every now and again. The special moves that each character has is very similar from each other with maybe different damage values and visuals with an upgrade system that feels tacked on because you don't seem to gain anything new aside from statistical buffs. The auto-targeting system is very annoying because of how often I wanted to hit a certain enemy only to have the game force me to hit something else resulting in me fighting against the system in addition to hide what I assume very dodgy hitboxes.

Okay so what about the co-op elements? First off, the Left 4 Dead comparison is completely false. Left 4 Dead has specials that have abilities that can immobilize you until death requiring teammates to rescue you. Grimm Eclipse has enemies that do none of that, so I think it's fairer to compare the enemies to something like Nazi Zombie Army in which every enemy is feasible to kill no matter what weapon you take while playing solo. Aside from getting extra xp for reviving, why even bother reviving your teammates when they can respawn in about 45 seconds and the last person standing can just kite the Grimm around the map? In a nutshell, the biggest sin for the co-op elements is that there is absolutely no team synergy and feels tacked on. Perhaps they'll address this at a later time, but it still has to be noted regardless.

I would have understood why people are going to go on the hate train for complaining so much as to saying but the game's in early access so of course it's going to be like that"
recommended: how is the game going to improve if these flaws aren't pointed out? I like the web show
hoursPlayed: but how can I even say the same thing with the game being as it is now? To me
voteText: this game was pushed out way too early to be even worth $15. They should have delayed its early access release for a few more months to add more content and flesh out its gameplay to make it stand out from other beat'em ups on the market other than it being sold on the franchise alone. For now
helpfulPercent: the game is competent at what it's trying to do
votesHelpful: but if this was not a RWBY game
votesTotal: I would have been much more negative than I am now."

Early Access Review

I don't do reviews often. However I'm a pretty big fan of RWBY. the show to me has always seemed perfect for a video game. Thankfully I think the basics are already there and pretty good. Let me start by saying, this is Early Access so whilst I will mention the issues, I expect them to be patched over time and if they are, then they're null and void, obviously.

So, it's an arena fighting game, sort of. If you're familiar with RWBY, then you know that the universe of the show features some pretty bombastic fights. Acrobatics, juggling, magical stuff. A gun thats also a scythe. These are all represented in the game.

The combat is however, maybe too simple for those of you expecting combos and specials. One attack key, one Shoot" key for long range stuff. It makes things somple

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, RWBY: Grimm Eclipse is a great game, even if it's in early access. The combat's amazing and the characters are lovely. There are some flaws, but you don't really notice them as you play the game. I cannot wait to see the game develop further.

A few things that I would like to see in the future though, would have to be more characters from RWBY that we could play as, like Nora, Pyrrhah, etc, a game mode where you can fight other people in tournaments, and achievements. Adding the option to customize the characters into the game would be lovely too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is as of Patch 2:

In its current state, I can't reccomend the game for the asking price to anyone outside of the RWBY fanbase.  If you're a part of the RWBY fanbase, the cost is negligable - you've already bought it.  If you're a beat-em-up fan, it may get better later but right now, it's not what your looking.  There is not enough of a substantial game here to pay 15 USD.

Pros:
-Multiplayer works, and well.
-The co-op multiplayer chaos is fun for the brief time the game lasts.
-It's more RWBY, including lines delievered by the voice actors from the show.
-I haven't found any significant bugs, ctd's, while playing it.
-It looks good.  The environments and characters are all pleasant to look at.

Cons:
-It's short, a playthrough of the entire game can be completed in about an hour over four short levels.  Across four characters, you're looking at four hours of gameplay before the game becomes mechanically samey.
-There are some ballance issues accross the characters.
-No auto-lock or any way of telling where your attacks are going.  This makes ranged combat wierd.  Combined with the sometimes wonkey hit boxes your character will sometimes turn 180 from the enemy you were hitting to hit something else.
-Progression from a kill is granted only to the player that finished it, it undermines some support builds or builds that focus on single target damage in favor of aoe kill kill kill.  It also makes it competitive to get that extra kill to get that extra xp.
-The game feels lonely, despite being a co-op game.  There is little incentive to synergize builds and attacks, the progression system of -last hit gets the xp- actually disincentivises it and you are only aware of your team mates when one goes down so you can stand them up for the 50xp.
-Even if there are no game breaking bugs, there are still smaller ones - mostly animation bugs.
-Combat could have a little more depth then button mashing the melee button and occasionally firing an ability.
-The controls are not mappable in the game, they're fine for keyboard mouse but the controller controls are nowhere near as tight (Hold down a button and hit a button to activate one of the three specials for example).
-For being RWBY, the sound effects are a little off on the weapons.
-If you do not know anything about RWBY, the game will leave you confused.

If you enjoyed the show and want to play around with this game, then by all means, pick it up.  You'll probably enjoy watching it develop.  If you don't know anything about the show, you should probably stay away for now.
