reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would like to start this Review is saying i am a big fan or Rooster Teeth and RWBY so you could view my review being biased.

Anyway I would like to start by saying this game is insanely fun it plays well and although there is not much of the game at the moment I can see how in the future they will improve the game even more I also have played all the characters at the moment apart from Weiss and Yang who I haven’t done a full play though of them yet.

Each character has their own advantages and weakness's and with certain combos you can cover most of them.

Ruby Rose is the team’s AOE character with large a large spin attack that allows you to clean up most enemies that are surrounding you, another attack that allows you to deal large amounts of damage to any enemies that are in front of you and behind you, and finally she has a ranges shot effect that hits enemies around where the shot hits with certain effects that you unlock by playing the game. But she has the lowest health (That I have seen) Which means you will need another player to use her attacks effectively.

Yang is the tank of the group she has high health and abilities that if used when on low health they deal more damage than they would normally. The skills she has are she can slam down on the ground dealing damage to all enemies around her and knocking them back allowing her to move around a bit easier she also has an upward dash which allows for either Blake or Ruby to jump in and deal damage with their mid-air attacks and finally she has a dash forward punch allowing her to jump into crowds and start gaining aggro before team mates decide to join in. But she doesn’t have any long distance range attacks her shotgun gauntlets only allow to hit things at a close to medium range.

Blake is the damage dealer of the group she is very fast and when she gets a target she throws them into the air allowing team mates to deal damage without her getting in the way. Her abilities are quite lacking compared to the rest she has a clone ability where she jumps back leaving a shadow of herself which you can put special effects on after playing the game for a bit. She also has a dash ability that allows you to jump around enemy that are in close range of her allowing you to clean up most enemies or damage a large amount allowing for Ruby or Yang to clean up the rest and finally she has a defining (I will get onto the audio mess in a min) range attack which after a few levels you can level up to throw three at once this is the worst attack I have found because it does barely any damage and take too long to charge. But she has the second highest health and her basic range attack seems to have infinite range as long as there is nothing in the way which you would expect from Ruby seen as she has a sniper but oh well.

Weiss I don’t even know not played much of her sorry can’t give much of a review of her.

Other than that the only thing I think needs to be change is more levels. (which I guess will be added at some point) The audio needs a bit fix its way to loud even after turning it down in my volume mixer to 5% For real having headphones round my neck and It was still far too loud and to top it off there are some missing animations like the most noticeable is when you run down stairs or down a hill.

TDLR: Very good for the team’s first ever game and very early access but better than 90% of stuff on there

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game shows a lot of promise, even in it's early access state. It's extremely fun, especially with 3 friends, and for it to be this early access, it's very impressive. There aren't really any noted game-breaking bugs, there are a few balance issues and mechanic issues, but overall it's fairly solid. The only primary issue is that there is no in-game sound effect slider, which leaves gameplay to be eardrum-blowlingly loud. On first startup, game music and voices are also very loud, but in the options there is a spot to turn down the volume, but for sound effects there isn't, so they stay extremely loud.

Many other fans and I would certainly love to see a patch allowing better sounds control ASAP.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: New Review for 12/19/2015 @ 2:29 PM EST


The Game may still be a very early access version of a much greater dream but I highly reccomend it still for those who are fans of the show or new arrivals to Rooster Teeth. (Not much new has occurred except for new visuals and info from the dev team during the livestream. Review has not changed)

[PROS/CONS]
+Beautiful graphical design. very similar to the actual show's design which adds to the immersion
+Voice acting, while limited, is high quality. The girls, Ryan, and Joel all did fantastic work
+Diversity. Yes there may only be four levels and an equal number of Grimm types but let's remeber where the roots of this game were with one level and one type of enemy based on the older concept of the Beowolf.
+Online connectivity. practically seemless ability to connect to matches and lobbies and no lag if a player drops mid game

-limited worlds/levels. As stated before, there are only four levels and those four levels are also highly restricted to a linear path. Hopefully the Game Dev team at Rooster Teeth will expand upon the limits of the levels they have (Can be forgiven thanks to the announced forever fall map in early 2016)
-Skill menu is too small. The choices in what to spend your skill points are still in the early stages so there aren't many things to put your points towards as many are locked away behind challenges
-Combat needs to be worked on. This goes as the most urgent of gameplay updates to me. there is only a dodge, no blocking and enemies gain both invincibility and speed during attacks making it tough to counter if at all. The addition of Lock on is also a must as ranged attacks are a real crapshoot for if you're gonna hit
-Only four characters. Yes I know, Team RWBY is the lead group but I would love to see the ability to play as JNPR, CFVY or even non Beacon affilitated teams like SSSN.
-More grimm are needed. Bring on swarms of Nevermores or giant Deathstalkers
-No boss fights. I want the Defend the control point" system to include a major boss at the end of each wave defense segment (4 waves of normal enemies/pack leaders and then one fight against a Giant Grimm or equivilant boss)
-Difficulty based lobbies. As of right now
date: difficulty adjusts to player count. i would love to see specific chosen difficulty (from easy or trainee
recommended:
to Very hard or True Huntsman or something)

[RECENT CHANGES]
Two patches have come out since My review of the game. These mostly adress preformance issues and don't work towards the combat system or the skill menus of the characters but they do make the game feel a bit smoother. Which is always an added bonus. There are also more breakable objects to find xp orbs in and while I didn't ask for it I'll welcome it all the same.

[WHAT I WOULD WANT UPDATED IMMEDIATELY]
First off
hoursPlayed: Fix the ranged attacks
voteText: if nothing else. Blake's ranged attack is too quick and overpowered. Ruby can only do three shot bursts and count your lucky stars for hitting something all three shots in a row (Saving grace is her personal armor piercing upgrade which allows you to damage the tougher enemies like Borbatusks and Ursa). Yang fires shots with a cone shape animated blast but from what I've seen the bullets still fire in straight lines. Weiss' attack is too slow compared to everyone else in the ranged catagory.\n\nSecondly
helpfulPercent: Lock on would be a godsend especially for challenge related skill use since it is very easy to miss an attack or do a combo straight out of the field of enemies.\n\nThird. Larger level scale
votesHelpful: the number of invisible walls are too damn high!\n\nStill
votesTotal: after a week and only two patches the game in my opinion is worth the time and money
votesFunny: now if you excuse me
commentsCount: I have challenges to complete and skills to unlock. Happy hunting

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Much of anything I could say has already been mentioned. The sound is design will get worked on, animations will be smoothed out, combos probably expanded (and shown in some sort of tutorial, hopefully), and I don't get motion sick.
One of the only things that get me is the combo meter. It seems to reset after a certain amount of time of not hitting anything. Some sort of indication of how long it will last will really help players gauge who to engage when in combat. It's also a pain regaining specials when the only one left standing is a big ♥♥♥ Beowulf who won't stagger and apparently has heat seeking claws.
Regarding the camera, it's movement is a bit stiff, and gets cramped near walls. This is really only a problem for me during combat, when my thumb is occupied with combos and can't tweak the camera to see my surroudings. Panning the camera out in combat or allowing it to move slowly and smoothly to get as much of the action would be a great addition. Until humans get two right thumbs, this camera's gonna need some work.
Besides all that, I'm having fun with the game. I do wish that the skills gained through leveling would stay, even if we have to get the xp over again.

p.s: After playing for a few more hours, one suggestion I have is to allow the number of hits you have on the combo meter to affect how much xp you get. For the purposes of the beta, this would only affect multiplayer; since, the only way to get the cap is to completely dominate the field. But, in the main game, hopefully a better fleshed out combat system will warrant more complex perk trees, and reward players who use their perks effectivelywith more xp. I don't mind having to choose perks to employ. Actually, knowing that I'll eventually have every single skill in the perk trees is sort of boring to me.

Cuz Steam is a pain in the balls, I loosely recommend this game. For now, just to test it. We'll see how this turns out.

As of 5/18
By now, I got a really good look at the the controls for all the characters, and I really like how they all play and their subtle differences in attack combos. The extra features added to combat are a welcome change as well; like the heavy attacks, ranged and stagger attacks becoming the upgradeable abilities, and enemies breaking through our combos if we go too long, forcing a dodge. It's so good to see RT sticking with this game, and it's potential is insane. But, I have only one major gripe. While the character models did get a very nice touch up, they look like cabbage patch kids in the face. Maybe that's just a result of the new style that they have now, but I really, really like the way looked before.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cannot emphasize enough how much fun this game is to play with friends. It's still early access, with bugs and only one campaign, and we're still sinking hours into it without a second thought! The gameplay is reminiscent of a Warriors game (Dynasty, Samauri, etc), which is a huge bonus in my opinion. Plus, it's a game made by the company that made the show. So you know there'll never be a problem with sub-par story, or mismatched voice acting, or anything like that. It's just like playing an episode of the show itself.
That said, if you don't have friends to play with, it loses some appeal. You can join in random games, but it's just not the same. I highly recommend finding someone to play with, the more the merrier!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated 03/16/16
As of now it's good for an Early Access game. Content here is really small having only about 5 missions but I enjoyed the 1 hour of gameplay I had. Music is alot like the show which is great. Recommended to most people but not for the people who likes lots of game content.

But now with the addition of a revamped combat system gameplay is much better. The only things needed are more missions and the story mode. Recommended to play with friends and now worth the price. Still the combat has things that won't show out of the box where I had to figure out how to chain team attacks. Only one game breaking glitch happened to me were one of the players disconnected and a door that should open stayed closed. Anyway the level system still needs a step up as shared xp is better rather than solo xp because someone else can last hit and they receicve the xp.

Nice things:
Music is on point.
Gameplay is action-packed
Really stable for an Early-Access game(Glitches occur but mostly fine.
Pretty graphics (I forget to walk just by looking at the lighting effects and scenery)

In the middle
Team RWBY feels the same on combat but distinct enough to know who they are in the team. *A little better because their skills tend to stand out now because of the combat revision.

Not so nice things
Not a lot of content (They just rolled out a beta update and that is just it)
Occasional glitches (Understandable and mostly minor)
People leaving games frequently ( I had a full team on the 1st mission and it went down to 2 of us on the 3rd one). Playing with friends can fix this but solo players will find this annoying

Potentials and things I want
A really robust system for combat ( Something more than this MOBA style abilities system)   * Just a bit more tweaking to the combat like heavy combo chains less animation stagger when using heavy attacks and it will be great.( Counters are OP so please fix)
Characters, more of them ( I want to see Team FNKY and JNPR )
Mission Diversity ( Defend X and Fight off Y waves of enemies will be boring for about 10 hours most games have)
An offline singleplayer mode with or without AI companions ( Coding the AI might be hard because the team working on the games only have a few people working on it.)
A lock on system like Metal Gear Rising or Kingdom Hearts where there is a soft lock on nearby enemies and a manual lock where you want to target an enemy in longer ranges.
Color swaps if somebody is playing the same character, it get confusing really close.

I really enjoyed the short time I was playing this game. Kudos to RT for making this and developing the game. More content and play time will come so buy this game on the coming Steam Sales that will come.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why did I recommend this?
I'm not going to wall of text with you but after 109+ hours in this game in Steam release.
Playing this far before Rooster Teeth decided to indulge in it; when it was a mediafire download fan project. How do I think they have executed it? Let's find out.

+Pros:

-You like hack'n'slash? Good; its for you.

-Beautiful Environments? Good; it relatively polished.

-Button prompts and response with a controller aspect is well thought out.

-The fact that I don't need a third party program to use said controller and have it automatically recognized is a big plus.

-All in all if you are a fan of the show and just want to chill with some friends or join a lobby. Good you will have fun with it.

+Cons:

-No way to select level designation.

-No real way to see who is in the team; character wise, before joining a game.

-Though the button combo presses are solid; the inevitable bug exists with team attacks not working correctly.

-Coding and generalized optimization fixes need to be done to make it a smoother experience.

The Pros; in my eyes, over-weigh the Cons here. For a small 20 USD you can get a package yes; and yes, its Early Access. But Rooster Teeth has never let me down as far as solid product as a customer and a subscriber to them for years. In short, you should get it to support it as a development and learning process for them and if you just love the show; as well as the game type. I've been suckered into A+ titles and gotten far less of an experience and fun out of it.
How I got to 109+ hours I really don't know, more so I was looking for every nook and cranny to get a bug or to see something that coders or other reviewers didn't; as well as enjoying the game along the way. And I plan on putting more hours in and to support everything this great company has offered in a fun little package.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So here's my thoughts on RWBY: Grimm Eclipse [Combat Revision]
First of all, [Combat Revision] would be an awesome name for a stand. Secondly, lets see the Pros and Cons:

Pros:Awesome new combat system, I felt the old one was a bit too hasty and could never find the correct skill button in time
Encountered as much bugs as SETI aliens, thought there was one time but still not sure
New camera system
C-C-COMBOS!
Some places were redisgned
Not screwed by Cinder in any way!

Cons:Not screwed by Cinder that way.
The aforementioned Camera system is a bit wonky
Some places were redisgned
For Oobleck's sake, not enough CFVY!

Well, for now that's all. Oh wait! To not just be some jerk telling what's wrong with the game, here, some suggestions how to make it better!
Obviously, most of all, right now the wonky camera system is my issue, I'm gonna take down the mouse sensitivity by a lot, still, I think the camera handling would be better if you could set the camera to be not independent from the character, e.g.: The character turns with the camera, would help a lot on us, FPS fans. If you make this option a tickable box then even those whom would have an issue with this option, couldn't whine. Oh! And of course, we need some CFVY now, or JNPR, either way it is a cool game, despite it isn't complete yet, which to say, not bad considering the team's size. Nevertheless I recommend this game, to those whom like Hack 'n' slash games or anime styled games or just RWBY in general.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun for a bit but it lacks alot. the game is very short which i would not be so against if it wasn't so repeditive. the game feels like an early access game and feels like it needs more to it.

The game has a max level of 10 and the game is too short for you to unlock the challenge skills and in some cases you have to Nerf yourself if you want to unlock another ability and wait to spend your skill points for the challenge skills (which in a team based game only hampers your progress ).

there is no Exp share even if you deal the most damage to an enemy whoever gets the kill gets the Exp.

and there are very little variety of enemies with a unique feel, most of them are the same but with more health and exp

THE GOOD PARTS:

So there are 4 characters with there own unique abilites.

The game is challenging and the animations are nice.

If you want more games by rooster teeth buy this game.

And despite the flaws i still get the feeling that the GameDevs care about the game.


I like rooster teeth, i like the RT content. i grew up on RvB and have been watching it since season 1 BUT if i want them to improve i Need to critisise them. I most Certainly want more RT games (which would pretty much only be RvB at this point and that's unlikely since its so tightly connected to halo) and i look forward to seeing the games that they may produce later. BUT alas i cannot recommend this game to anyone for if not for the RT name i would not have bought this game myself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Much of anything I could say has already been mentioned. The sound is design will get worked on, animations will be smoothed out, combos probably expanded (and shown in some sort of tutorial, hopefully), and I don't get motion sick.
One of the only things that get me is the combo meter. It seems to reset after a certain amount of time of not hitting anything. Some sort of indication of how long it will last will really help players gauge who to engage when in combat. It's also a pain regaining specials when the only one left standing is a big ♥♥♥ Beowulf who won't stagger and apparently has heat seeking claws.
Regarding the camera, it's movement is a bit stiff, and gets cramped near walls. This is really only a problem for me during combat, when my thumb is occupied with combos and can't tweak the camera to see my surroudings. Panning the camera out in combat or allowing it to move slowly and smoothly to get as much of the action would be a great addition. Until humans get two right thumbs, this camera's gonna need some work.
Besides all that, I'm having fun with the game. I do wish that the skills gained through leveling would stay, even if we have to get the xp over again.

p.s: After playing for a few more hours, one suggestion I have is to allow the number of hits you have on the combo meter to affect how much xp you get. For the purposes of the beta, this would only affect multiplayer; since, the only way to get the cap is to completely dominate the field. But, in the main game, hopefully a better fleshed out combat system will warrant more complex perk trees, and reward players who use their perks effectivelywith more xp. I don't mind having to choose perks to employ. Actually, knowing that I'll eventually have every single skill in the perk trees is sort of boring to me.

Cuz Steam is a pain in the balls, I loosely recommend this game. For now, just to test it. We'll see how this turns out.

As of 5/18
By now, I got a really good look at the the controls for all the characters, and I really like how they all play and their subtle differences in attack combos. The extra features added to combat are a welcome change as well; like the heavy attacks, ranged and stagger attacks becoming the upgradeable abilities, and enemies breaking through our combos if we go too long, forcing a dodge. It's so good to see RT sticking with this game, and it's potential is insane. But, I have only one major gripe. While the character models did get a very nice touch up, they look like cabbage patch kids in the face. Maybe that's just a result of the new style that they have now, but I really, really like the way looked before.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Much of anything I could say has already been mentioned. The sound is design will get worked on, animations will be smoothed out, combos probably expanded (and shown in some sort of tutorial, hopefully), and I don't get motion sick.
One of the only things that get me is the combo meter. It seems to reset after a certain amount of time of not hitting anything. Some sort of indication of how long it will last will really help players gauge who to engage when in combat. It's also a pain regaining specials when the only one left standing is a big ♥♥♥ Beowulf who won't stagger and apparently has heat seeking claws.
Regarding the camera, it's movement is a bit stiff, and gets cramped near walls. This is really only a problem for me during combat, when my thumb is occupied with combos and can't tweak the camera to see my surroudings. Panning the camera out in combat or allowing it to move slowly and smoothly to get as much of the action would be a great addition. Until humans get two right thumbs, this camera's gonna need some work.
Besides all that, I'm having fun with the game. I do wish that the skills gained through leveling would stay, even if we have to get the xp over again.

p.s: After playing for a few more hours, one suggestion I have is to allow the number of hits you have on the combo meter to affect how much xp you get. For the purposes of the beta, this would only affect multiplayer; since, the only way to get the cap is to completely dominate the field. But, in the main game, hopefully a better fleshed out combat system will warrant more complex perk trees, and reward players who use their perks effectivelywith more xp. I don't mind having to choose perks to employ. Actually, knowing that I'll eventually have every single skill in the perk trees is sort of boring to me.

Cuz Steam is a pain in the balls, I loosely recommend this game. For now, just to test it. We'll see how this turns out.

As of 5/18
By now, I got a really good look at the the controls for all the characters, and I really like how they all play and their subtle differences in attack combos. The extra features added to combat are a welcome change as well; like the heavy attacks, ranged and stagger attacks becoming the upgradeable abilities, and enemies breaking through our combos if we go too long, forcing a dodge. It's so good to see RT sticking with this game, and it's potential is insane. But, I have only one major gripe. While the character models did get a very nice touch up, they look like cabbage patch kids in the face. Maybe that's just a result of the new style that they have now, but I really, really like the way looked before.

This game is fun for a bit but it lacks alot. the game is very short which i would not be so against if it wasn't so repeditive. the game feels like an early access game and feels like it needs more to it.

The game has a max level of 10 and the game is too short for you to unlock the challenge skills and in some cases you have to Nerf yourself if you want to unlock another ability and wait to spend your skill points for the challenge skills (which in a team based game only hampers your progress ).

there is no Exp share even if you deal the most damage to an enemy whoever gets the kill gets the Exp.

and there are very little variety of enemies with a unique feel, most of them are the same but with more health and exp

THE GOOD PARTS:

So there are 4 characters with there own unique abilites.

The game is challenging and the animations are nice.

If you want more games by rooster teeth buy this game.

And despite the flaws i still get the feeling that the GameDevs care about the game.

I most Certainly want more RT games (which would pretty much only be RvB at this point and that's unlikely since its so tightly connected to halo) and i look forward to seeing the games that they may produce later. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright so i have watched the Anime and when i Played this Game it Felt like i was in the Anime.
It is a Awesome Hack And Slash Game especially for RWBY Fans like me :D
of course this game still needs more time for the Developement but i think Roosterteeth didn't think it's gonna get Greenlit so Fast haha^^

So now to the Pros of this Game:

- Graphic Style is just like in the Anime
- Music and Voices from the Anime
- Good Performance
- Easy Server/Lobby System (No Port Forwarding needed)
- Good Controls (Easy to Use and Understand)
- Full Controller Support
- Good Developement <3

Now to the Cons of this game: (Early Access)

- Bugs (not Game affecting Bugs)
- The Game Doesn't Save

After All it's still Early Access so in a Nutshell This Game is great to Play with Friends and RWBY Fans Feel like they are actually in the Anime.

My Ideas for the Final Game:

- Story Mode (Best whould be one Singleplayer Campaign and One Multiplayer Campaign)
- Arena Mode (1v1, 2v2, 4v4, FFA up to 8 or even 16 Players (Optimal 32 Players))
- Free Mode (Exploring The World of Remnant and Fight against Random Monsters on the Map)
- Wave/Horde Mode (Fight Against an Unlimited Amount of Monsters Until the Last Survivor Dies)
- Shops and Small Villages to Buy Equipment and Potions
- Weapon Modifications
- Changeable Clothes/Armor
- Charackter Creator (Not 100% Necessary)
- More Playable Charackters from the Anime
- Boss Fights
- Day/Night Cycle
- Multiple Combos
- Team Combos
- Special Abillities
- Yang's Rage Mode
- Steam Workshop (For All the Creative People out there :D)
- Long Skill Tree
- Death (instead of Respawning after 45 sec you'll Die and Respawn after All Enemies are gone or The Full Wave is Over)
- Trading System
- Throwable Items (Shurikens, Bombs, etc.)
- Secrets and Easter Eggs (For All the Explorers and Bug Users out There xD)
- Toggle between Third- and Firstperson Mode (Not 100% Necessary)
- Tutorial (My Idea for the Tutorial whould be Like in the Anime You'll get Thrown Down in The Forest and have to find the Relict and fight against the Grimms)
- Split Screen (Up to 4 Players on one Computer) (Joystick Needed)
- Cutscenes
- 3-5 Difficulties


That's All from my Review of the Game RWBY: Grimm Eclipse
I Wish Everyone a Great Time Playing this Game \*^-^*/

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nKeeping in mind that this game is still Early Access, its very fun. The gameplay seems to move fairly smoothly and the abilities and weapons make each character a new experience. The lack of a lock on mechanic hurts this game a bit, as sometimes you can just fly through a group of enemies and only hit 2 out of 10 of them. The game is a bit too simple, as you only have two attack buttons, no real combos, and a basic jump and dodge. The game has a long way to go, but it's honestly amazing once you consider this is the earliest stage of the game out. Once this game gets some good updates, it'll be an amazingly fun hack and slash.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With almost 5 hours under my belt I feel as if I can safely recomend this game to anyone interested.

Pro Ramble:
What I love most about this game is the feeling of each attack knocking back your opponent. It feels a lot like Dragon Nest which is one of my favorite games due to the fighting mechanics. I also played the first version of Grimm Eclipse and loved that as well. As soon as I saw the Early Access trailer I immediately loaded up Steam and bought it. Next thing I knew I'm playing Ruby while singing a messed of version of Willy Wonka's A world of pure imagination
date:
changing imagination to decaptitation. In fact, when I went to get a drink of water after playing, I then realized that I had played until 10:30ish when I meant to be done at 8:00 to watch the Flash.

Con Ramble:
My only complaints are the random bugs here and there, like hit box missing and awkward slope sliding. This is understandable as it just came out and I know RoosterTeeth is committed to their fanbase. The campaign is also incomplete though I feel like they did that on purpose... They also need to add control editors as I am too used to pressing enter to chat with other people.

Other Rambling
While this game is early access it is well worth the $15.00 and just play around even without friends. The game is easy enough to where you feel godlike on the battlefield and hard enough to where you need to use strategy to complete your goal. In all honesty it doesn't really matter that the campaign isn't finished yet. RoosterTeeth likes to hang all of us on a cliff anyway, even in video games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are a fan of RWBY and hack and slash team games you will love this.

If you are not a fan of RWBY but are a fan of hack and slash games you will enjoy this greatly!

Cons:

- Animation sometimes bugs out but not very often.

- Some of the talking is to quiet. However this seems to be because the characters VA didn't do the lines so they made them quieter as to be less noticeable.

- Performance is a issue the game has yet to be optimized as it just came out of beta today but its still playable.

- No remapping of controls.

- It has its fair share of glitches none game breaking (But some come close IE. Your chat window goes away and won't come back)

Pros:

+ Sound track! While most of the game has background music boss fights have songs from the RWBY OST.

+ Each character feels really different. I have seen people say this is not the case but I have played as all 4 that are out now and each one plays different.

Ruby plays as heavy damage and crowd control. Her abilities are tailored to be able to take on hoards head on.

Weiss plays as support. She can freeze enemies and knock them back away from her team which is helpful for reviving.

Blake is less straightforward. In the game you get special blips to use special moves. To get one blip you have to fill up the combo bar without getting hit. On her own she deals fast low damage but fills up her bar quickly. Her special attacks are pretty good ranging from crowd control to boss killing moves.

Yang plays as two ways that I have found. She is either crowd control or a tank. Her attacks and special upgrades allow her to take a lot of damage and when her Aura is depleted she gets a full special bar. This combined with high health and wide weapon spread makes her perfect to take enemies.

+ The upgrading. Each character has 3 specials and a general for upgrading. The specials vary from character to character but the general is mostly the same except for 2 upgrades special to each character.

+ Its a challenging game. Most of the Grimm are weak alone but can quickly overwhelm you. To add to that you have Major" Grimm which are much stronger versions and can be tricky on their own.

+ A good variety of Grimm to fight.

You have 5 types to fight each with three upgrades.

Creeps
Beowulfs
Boarbatusk
Ursa
And a new mutated nameless Grimm.

In the end I would give RWBY:GE a 8/10"

If you are a fan of the show, then you will definitely enjoy this game. Since it is on early access, it’s bound to have bugs and not all of the intended features will have been implemented yet. Right now, there is just a short unfinished campaign which you can play co-op.

This game is fun even in early access so you can only imagine the potential it has when it’s completed.
The game looks cool. It’s got a potato setting. The characters look cool. The environment is cool. The attacks are cool. What else can you ask for in an early access game?

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game is a lot of fun, but there are things that could be improved, such as the invisible walls and their limits, because Blake can gain serious height and go almost out of bounds (in one situation, I was stuck behind an invisible wall for a portion of a level after using Blake's combo). also, I think health should be displayed independently of Aura, maybe as a second bar underneath Aura after Aura is gone. Apart from that, I can't think of many other improvements that you haven't thought of already (such as more levels and characters). So I will leave this review with the fact that this game is incredibly fun and entertaining, but it needs improvements, and I assume they will be made further down the line, and so would like to thank you for them. Hope this is helpful, and thank you for creating such an awesome game. 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to start this out by saying that this is a really fun game it's great feeling to fight tons of grim as the characters of RWBY in a team based setting. I think the game-play is decently fun and the story is alright. So when you read the rest of the review, keep in mind that I DO like your game, I just think that it could be improved in multiple ways.

[If you are reading this to decide weather or not you want to buy it, stop here. The rest is for the developers.]

My major problems with this game revolve around how much so many parts of the game feel the same. After about the 10th time playing through the campaign I have almost completely memorized all of the encounters. My biggest suggestion to improve this feature is by potentially randomizing the spawn locations of the relics and boxes, and putting a small randomization in the spawn rates of the mobs that we will be fighting. Also, all of the characters feel, for the most part, the same. The abilities seem to be lined up like this: AoE Damage/Utility, high damage single target, long range damage. To improve on this you could potentially either make it so that each character has a truly unique move set, or give each character the option between 5 or more moves that they would simply chose 3 of. Another way to add customization and diversity is by allowing people to upgrade their character with bonuses to health/speed/skill damage/flat damage/ attacking speed/whatever you want (look at the mod system in Warframe to get a better idea of what I'm talking about[I'm not saying copy the whole system, just the general concept of mods and slots]). As for the basic attacks, I suggest looking up the game Vindictus" and trying to implement an attack/combo system like they have for their characters. It doesn't have to be identical
date: but there is currently little point to doing anything other than spam left click with the occasional tap of shift to dodge or space to jump. Alternatively
recommended: you could take a note from
hoursPlayed: again
voteText: the game "Warframe" by implementing differences in the attack combos based off of movement or pauses in stead of right clicks. This might solve the repetitive nature of the current combat system and make the game a little more enjoyable
helpfulPercent: but that is not what I think the main problem of the game is. As far as I'm concerned
votesHelpful: the main problem with this game appears to be intention.\n\nAs far as I can tell
votesTotal: your current intention with this game is to make a fun game for people to buy
votesFunny: play a few times
commentsCount: then drop. Decently fun
column16: good deal
column17: maybe pick up every so often to play with friends
column18: but not anything truly amazing. THIS WOULD BE A TERRIBLE WASTE. This is a fact that I can not stress enough: this could be an amazing game that people will still be coming back to when RWBY is in season 10 (if the series has that many seasons)
column19: or potentially outlast the actual show! All you would have to do is follow a simple formula
column20: and this game could go from an alright game that friends play every so often
column21: to a game big enough to compete with AAA titles.\n\nIt may seem like this is to small of a game to ever grow to the sizes that I may have mentioned
column22: but all you have to do is 1 simple*(not really that simple) thing: continue to release content. Add more campaigns
column23: continue to release new characters(it's not like you have any shortage to chose from)
column24: add cosmetic options(either in sets or for individual slots like chest
column25: boots
column27: head
column29: and even survival modes. Another way to increase interest in this game is by introducing a competitive scene
column30: by having endurance challenges and/or races in preset unique situations. The rewards could be in-game currency (I'll get to that in the next section)
column32: or even potentially real RWBY merchandise. Holiday events are also another way to get attention and returning players. If you continue to add content and host events
column33:
you will have people coming back to this game till the end of time.

Now you may be currently thinking "aside from appeasing our fan after the complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T WE JUST PULLED IN THE LAST TWO EPISODES OF SEASON 3!" (*takes deep breath*) "Why would we do this? New content is expensive to produce and there no assurance we would get that much out of it." In reality you could make it quite profitable in one of two ways. The first of which I will call the "EA approach" and the second I will call the "Dangerous but Loved approach"

The EA approach is quite simple
column34: and DLC is the name of the game. Just look at Payday 2
column35: a very simple game (that is in my opinion isn't even that amazing) that has lasted far longer than it should have by a constant stream of frankly impressive DLC and developing content. You could release characters in team based packs or individually
column37: and a billion different other things that people could buy for a (pleasepleaseplease) low price. The good part about this method
column38: you will almost certainly make money off of each expansion you release. The down-side
column39: people will hate you. You'll be accused you being money-grabbers and probably lose a good portion off players and fans. This is not the method I would personally suggest. Instead I would suggest...\n\nThe Dangerous but Loved approach. The idea is that you release all of your expansions and DLC free of charge. Any new content that could affect game-play you give to all your players completely free. Now hold on just one second before you call this method financial suicide
column40: you still could make decent profit this way
column41: but it would require a significantly larger amount of work. The idea is that you would pump out as much cosmetic DLC as feasibly possible. You could buy these cosmetics either with direct money transfers or an in-game currency that you purchase with real money. These cosmetics could easily be costumes (like previously mentioned)
column42: but you could also offer alternate skill effects
column44: but you could really do anything to just make them look different. You could introduce pets that don't actually do anything
column45: just follow you around and look cute. I'm sure you can see the reason this is called the Dangerous but Loved approach
column46: there is a significant risk of not making as much money as you may expect
column47: but those who can't afford that much can still enjoy the game at a very low cost. While it may seem that you might not even break even with this payment model
column48: I would suggest you look at Grinding Gears Games. They are a small game company that popped up only a few years ago
column49: and is using almost this exact same model for an entirely free-to-play game. You could also take a not from their supporter pack by releasing time limited exclusive packs of cosmetics and real life merchandise. With your current fan base and the quality of the game as it is before you make any of my previously mentioned changes (if you do that is)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ATTENTION: BIASED PLAYER
So, I have been waiting for this game ever since Grim Eclipse. (No, this game is not a sequel. It was created from Grim Eclipse.) As soon as it came out, I got it. For die-hard RWBY fans, Grimm Eclipse is a must-have. If you have never seen RWBY but want to play this game, I recommend you go watch volumes 1, 2, and 3.

PROS:
-Amazing gameplay
-Automatic Target Lock system
-4-Player Co-op (you can also play with your friends)
-Still in Beta

CONS:
-Lag (EDIT 12/18/15: Even after Patch #2, it's still really laggy)
-Camera doesn't rotate if you run in a different direction
-Combos aren't the easiest to get
-Awkward walk/run transition
-It's still in Beta


So, if you ARE a die-hard RWBY fan or you are willing to go watch RWBY right now, I definitely recommend this game. If you are not willing to go watch RWBY or are not really interested, I do not recommend this.

FOOTNOTE: I have not played this game very long at the time this was written.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was the Ice Queen leading a Cat-Girl army.
Need I say more.

(More serious review:)
I have loved playing this game since I first bought it. There are a few quirks with rendering, holes in the map and still needs to be balanced more. but those are all minor problems. The balance issue doesn't really effect me since I almost always end up on the top of the leaderboard at the end of every game (both kills and deaths:( ). If you are a fan you really need to buy the game while its in early access since the price is said to go up soon enough.

-Every character has an individual skill tree with three specials and two unlockable upgrades.
-The specials include an area of affect, individual target and directional.
-You have to reach a certain amount of kills to unlock several of the third tier upgrades for the specials.
-Of the two individual upgrades, one usually requires a certain amount of special attack kills and the other is only unlocked when you reach level 10, but it stays unlocked for future playthroughs.
-Other upgrades include: increased health, increased aura (pretty much shields), decreased aura recharge time/delay, decreased revive time (requires 5 revives to unlock), and increased amount of special attack points.
-Only has one champaign but will have a total of three

Recommendations:
-keyboard is fine but prolonged playing hurts your fingers. USE A CONTROLLER
-Always get the Lvl 10 upgrade on your first lvl up (assuming youve made it lvl 10 in a previous playthrough)
-get the revive upgrade early on
-locate all the artifacts

personally, Yang is my least favourite in game character

The potential for this game is very high with the possibility for a great workshop community for different skins and campaigns (if their is a workshop section, but the guys at RT have a good sense of humor and are pretty loose so I wouldn't rule out workshop). More characters are potentially possible. I personally don't like the idea of character creation but it seems to be heavily supported by the RWBY community.

IT IS ONLY EARLY ACCESS but is surprisingly polished. I have only encountered one bug that interferred with game play but I still recovered

Even if you aren't a RWBY fan, you will be after one playthrough

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'd like to be clear on something first: as of right now, the game is nigh unplayable(edit: with the most recent patch, framerate is up to playable on all settings, which vastly improves playability and experience) on my computer due to framrate issues. Even on potato settings, the game is jittery as hell, and I have a GTX 860M which should be able to run a game of this graphical quality with ease (with fast paced combat, a good framerate really improves the experience). Also, the game is very early in development and lacks any real polish either in the UI or the combat. So why the recommendation, you ask? Well, I'm a huge fan of the series, and in particular I think they've done a fantastic job setting up a universe where a game like this has the potential to be INCREDIBLE. The show delivers each character with a unique weapon and combat style, which would make for a perfect cooperative game with players that take on different roles and mesh with each other to balance out strengths and weaknesses. The only thing that the devs need is the time and money to create it. Should you buy the game right now if you've never heard of RWBY? Probably not (unless you are very interested in the final product and think you'll buy the game eventually). Should you buy the game if you're a fan of the show and want to support the game, whether or not the final product meets expectations? Yes. I 100% encourage you to throw money at the things you love.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is a little rough around the edges but it shows a lot of promise for what it can be. The hack and slash aspect isn't as straight forward as one may think. Charging into a group of enemies will get you mowed down. Tactical retreat, hit and run, and attacking with your allies is the way to survive. The action and use of source material makes this the best in my books. I understand this is an early access we have so far but here are some things I've noted while playing thus far.

The settings menu doesn't seem to like saving the previous session settings. I toned down the resolution and quality for my first time playing. I have an older machine so I didn't want to stress test it just yet. When I went to change the video quality, the resolution also changed to 1920x1200 without my input. The second time I opened the game, it forgot I turned on subtitles.

There are certain gameplay aspects that I found to be lacking. Whenever static artwork like a speaking characters face was shown, it was a low resolution but blown up image. I hope this will be resolved in the successive releases. The fighting audio seems to overpower speech audio. Perhaps you can have all sound lower slightly when a character is talking?

I know animation work is difficult and doubly so for a gameplay where the models are at the player's whim. The animations are pretty good for walking on even ground and jumping but there was an odd falling animation and sound when going down a gentle decline. It also prevented additional movement input like jumping.

Is there a way to include mutators before the match? Perhaps having the option to prevent people from selecting the same characters. I also suggest a way of changing characters when changing levels.

These are probably the major issues that I have encountered. As for suggestions… the opening credit scene plays for too long, the main menu screen lacks a help option to see the button mapping, perhaps allowing button mapping in the settings menu, an extras menu option for tracking stats, concept art, artifacts found, stats on how many kills, and achievements, aura recharge upon leveling, and perhaps a UI upgrade to have a transparent backing to make it look similar to the phones or screens as shown in the series.

I’ve rambled on long enough. Good game so far but with a bit of polish, it can be great!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is beyond amazing. Starting out as a fan game, the main dev was contacted by Monty Oum less than 24 hours after launch, and it ended up being picked up by RoosterTeeth as an official game. And they have done a fantastic job. If you have any questions, I stream this game regularly at www.twitch.tv/victorsevengames and I would be happy to answer them.

Controls are tight. Movement neither feels too heavy nor too slidey and floaty. Combat is insanely fast. Think Devil May Cry on crack in a slightly Dynasty Warriors setting and X/Y combo relationship. Currently available are the four members of Team RWBY, each sporting their own strengths and weaknesses, and distinct play style.

The game feels a bit more like a demo than anything, showcasing the first four levels of the game, no story beyond Professor Port and Dr. Oobleck narrating your objectives. The levels include multiple sections which feel like Warframe style missions, from Exterminate sections to Defense sections before flowing to the next section.

All in all, one complete run through the current version of the game takes around an hour or so depending on how you play it. Even so, I still say it is well worth the $15, and a must-buy for any RWBY fan. Featuring all of the original voice actors (except Blake, whose actress hadn't recorded her lines yet at the time of release), there is some banter and funny quips during combat and certain sections of the game that make you smile in reminiscence of the show.

I have bought 7 copies of this game so far for friends, and still have 2 left for giveaways because I KNOW whoever wins them will love this game. Rock on, RoosterTeeth. And thank you, Mr. Jordan Scott for starting this project.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs far as I'm concerned this game is better than it was when it first came out, but still has quite a ways to go. reviewText:
Early Access Review

[TL;DR at bottom]

This game is definately for the shows audience as it takes place between two of the shows seasons. Meaning if you have not seen it, get on that RIGHT NOW. The game itself had a lot of thought put into it as each character has a different play style with its own strengths. Also, the combat is very solid as it is both fun and challenging at the same time. This helps point out a major part of this game: WORK TOGETHER. As this is still in early access, the levels are decently designed and the graphics of the game looks good, but the levels feel sort of empty or lacking life. Now this is a problem that will most likely be fixed as the developers actually finish the game. Also, it should be said that the game does run with very (I mean VERY) few glitches. Lastly the game can drop frames on ultra settings (or at least for me), even though my computer plays most games max settings, but other than than it is smooth.

TL;DR
This game is fun. If you are a fan of the show, definately pick it up. It's tons of fun with friends and at $15 it's a decent price.Well, I actually see it as more of an investment, but the game already is very good. So, pick it up and slay some grimm. Just be wary of ultra settings, but other than that it's fine. Also I recommend a gamepad as it was more comfortable for me.

Final Rating
8/10
It is fun and plays well, but lacks some content. However that will be fixed in the future, so why not get it?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: I am a wh*** for RWBY. I didn't even think twice about grabbing this on day one of early access.

Edit: I have now played through this about a dozen times. My opinions have not changed much.

I am aware that this is (very) early access, and anyone reading this should keep that in mind as well.

It's very rough and very simple. The visuals are pretty good, but the gameplay needs some help. Anyone who loves RWBY will love playing through this game... once or twice.

Story:

Err, it's kinda there? I can't really judge it, becaues you only get to play three stages so far, and you only get a brief glimpse of it. Basically, you find some tech lying around that belongs to a company that was supposed to have gone under when a city got overrun by grimm, thus taking out their headquarters and whatnot.

Visuals:

The art is fantastic. The characters are spot on and so are the grimm. For the most part, the particle effects from attacks and whatnot are pretty good too. Only issue I had is the shockwaves from some attacks look silly, since it's litterally a line of big, stone blocks flying through the air. But that's it.

The running animations are a bit weird though. I noticed that Weiss looks funny when she's sprinting" because it's basically just her normal run animation

And here's the important part. The gameplay is basically one big game of cat and mouse as you try to attack the enemies without getting smacked down. The enemies have no basic attacks. None. At all. This is what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most back when the demo was on the Rooster Teeth website.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game needs a lot of work done but I know RT will expand upon this game (I hope)

The first thing I want to address: The voice acting isn't good! I watched the show and the actresses do so much better in the show, I hope that the lines are re-recorded so that the acting sounds believable because I know they can act, also I think the actress for Blake was using a different mic because her voice sounded very low quality compared to the rest of the actors.

The game itself is visually appealing, however the models that you play as and fight against don't look like they belong there. The models look anime which is true to the show, but the maps look like an entire different art style. The best way I can describe it is think of the opening cutscene to Sonic '06 (for reference I love RWBY and am only making this comparison because I want this gme to succeed) where you have these final fantasy-esque graphics with detailed models and complicated lighting. And then Sahnich shows up looking totally out of place with a simple model and hardly any definition. I don't think this would be hard fix since your taking pixels OUT of the map textures.

Animations are nice but conflict with eachother animations when switching to a different task

Whenever you stop moving the running animation continues for a second making movement very awkward.

The combat gets repetitive quick, some good ways to fix this would be to add finishers or making it so you can use enemies against themselves. For example what if you could lead one of those boar grimm into a hoard of beowulfs stunning all enemies who are hit. Add collaboration to your combos by using duos of characters in a team.

The game takes no effort into explaining the story of RWBY, leaving newcomers to the franchise confused and with a bad taste in their mouth

Final Verdict: This game is unfinished obviously. But I still think its worth picking up. Once RT adds more content and fixes all the glitches I think it will be very fun. Monty be praised

Early Access Review

[Day 1 Review]
As a fan of the series I have to say that the game is really enjoyable and a fun experience overall.

I recommend purchasing the game only if you don't mind getting an incomplete and unoptimized game.

Pros
+ original voice actors
+ pretty visuals (the textures are a bit lacking tho, but you really don't notice that between fights)
+ simple skill/progression system (some more complexity wouldn't hurt)
+ potato quality
+ MORE RWBY!

Cons
- currently only has 4 chapters
- the music and voice volume is inconsistent
- can't remap controls
- graphical bugs, invisible walls (at the end of the first chapter in the final room near the secret area)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to start this out by saying that this is a really fun game it's great feeling to fight tons of grim as the characters of RWBY in a team based setting. I think the game-play is decently fun and the story is alright. So when you read the rest of the review, keep in mind that I DO like your game, I just think that it could be improved in multiple ways.

[If you are reading this to decide weather or not you want to buy it, stop here. The rest is for the developers.]

My major problems with this game revolve around how much so many parts of the game feel the same. After about the 10th time playing through the campaign I have almost completely memorized all of the encounters. My biggest suggestion to improve this feature is by potentially randomizing the spawn locations of the relics and boxes, and putting a small randomization in the spawn rates of the mobs that we will be fighting. Also, all of the characters feel, for the most part, the same. The abilities seem to be lined up like this: AoE Damage/Utility, high damage single target, long range damage. To improve on this you could potentially either make it so that each character has a truly unique move set, or give each character the option between 5 or more moves that they would simply chose 3 of. Another way to add customization and diversity is by allowing people to upgrade their character with bonuses to health/speed/skill damage/flat damage/ attacking speed/whatever you want (look at the mod system in Warframe to get a better idea of what I'm talking about[I'm not saying copy the whole system, just the general concept of mods and slots]). As for the basic attacks, I suggest looking up the game Vindictus" and trying to implement an attack/combo system like they have for their characters. It doesn't have to be identical

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ATTENTION: BIASED PLAYER
So, I have been waiting for this game ever since Grim Eclipse. (No, this game is not a sequel. It was created from Grim Eclipse.) As soon as it came out, I got it. For die-hard RWBY fans, Grimm Eclipse is a must-have. If you have never seen RWBY but want to play this game, I recommend you go watch volumes 1, 2, and 3.

PROS:
-Amazing gameplay
-Automatic Target Lock system
-4-Player Co-op (you can also play with your friends)
-Still in Beta

CONS:
-Lag (EDIT 12/18/15: Even after Patch #2, it's still really laggy)
-Camera doesn't rotate if you run in a different direction
-Combos aren't the easiest to get
-Awkward walk/run transition
-It's still in Beta


So, if you ARE a die-hard RWBY fan or you are willing to go watch RWBY right now, I definitely recommend this game. If you are not willing to go watch RWBY or are not really interested, I do not recommend this.

FOOTNOTE: I have not played this game very long at the time this was written.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although it's still lacking in content, which is no surprise since it's Early Access, it's certainly a very fun game to play. Be it solo or co-op with a couple of friends. The characters are well designed and the game world looks very much like the series' in terms of graphics.
The few challenges to unlock certain abilities make it more interesting and I believe the reset option in the settings will help bring back the fun when one has unlocked everything.

I can't wait for more chapters of the game as well as other playable teams. But in the mean time I will recommend this to any and all, so we can have quite a bit of fun waiting for the next episode of RWBY.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I gotta say, after finishing Chapter 1... I'm already in love with this game. This is very smooth and plays like a true hack-n-slash.  I found loving how all 4 played, and neither of the 4 are dull. They all have their strengths and amazing abilities. I'll cut it short and put into a bulleted list.

Pros:
-Game runs VERY smoothly.
-Controls don't feel clunky or terrible.
-The characters, even though there are 6 (Ruby, Blake, Weiss, Yang, Oobleck, and Port), are perfectly acted.
-Much replayability to get all abilities and hear all the unique dialouge.
-Multiple abilities for each character.
-Tense battles.
-Very few bugs.

Now I could go on and on about the pros, but that's to long of a list.

Cons:
-Graphics can glitch sometimes.
-Auto Aim is unbearable.
-Number of enemies can get extreme sometimes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRWBY: Grimm Eclipse is one of the best anime games I have ever played. I have watched all of the episodes up to Volume 3 Chapter 6, and the movesets of each character is well made to fit their abilities. I like the 4 person multiplayer, but as this game is currently in Early Access, there are only 4 characters to choose from. Hopefully, Rooster Teeth will decide to add in other teams besides Team RWBY, such as JNPR (Jaune, Nora, Pyrrha, and Lie Ren), CFVY (Coco, Fox, Velvet, and Yatsuhashi), and maybe some others. I appreciate the Dynasty Warriors type gameplay, but I feel there should be a few more Grimm to fight, as it feels too easy. Again, because this is Early Access, there are only 4 levels, Emerald Forest Parts 1 and 2, Mountain Glenn, and Underground Mountain Glenn, but more are to come. The music composed for this game is good, but I wouldn't mind hearing some songs from the show. I feel this could be integrated if each character gets an exclusive special that uses up the entire bar, and then the game plays the character's theme song, such as Red Like Roses for Ruby, I Burn for Yang, Mirror Mirror for Weiss, and From Shadows for Blake. I would recommend this game to fans of this show, for people looking for a nice Dynasty Warriors like fighter, and for people who want to get into this show.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI do love the fighting the Grimm and the co-op part of it, although a solo quest would be cool too with computer ai for the other three team members (this would help for people who don't have internet access all the time, kinda similar to what Dragon Age Origins does). Some customization would be nice and I loooove the fact that it's the original voice actors with creating a new storyline. I know it's early access so looking up the controls is good and all but a tutorial for new players always helps. So far my impression of the game is that it's really good and has a lot of potential to further expand the RWBY universe. Yay Rooster Teeth!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With almost 5 hours under my belt I feel as if I can safely recomend this game to anyone interested.

Pro Ramble:
What I love most about this game is the feeling of each attack knocking back your opponent. It feels a lot like Dragon Nest which is one of my favorite games due to the fighting mechanics. I also played the first version of Grimm Eclipse and loved that as well. As soon as I saw the Early Access trailer I immediately loaded up Steam and bought it. Next thing I knew I'm playing Ruby while singing a messed of version of Willy Wonka's A world of pure imagination
date:
changing imagination to decaptitation. In fact, when I went to get a drink of water after playing, I then realized that I had played until 10:30ish when I meant to be done at 8:00 to watch the Flash.

Con Ramble:
My only complaints are the random bugs here and there, like hit box missing and awkward slope sliding. This is understandable as it just came out and I know RoosterTeeth is committed to their fanbase. The campaign is also incomplete though I feel like they did that on purpose... They also need to add control editors as I am too used to pressing enter to chat with other people.

Other Rambling
While this game is early access it is well worth the $15.00 and just play around even without friends. The game is easy enough to where you feel godlike on the battlefield and hard enough to where you need to use strategy to complete your goal. In all honesty it doesn't really matter that the campaign isn't finished yet. RoosterTeeth likes to hang all of us on a cliff anyway, even in video games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are a fan of RWBY and hack and slash team games you will love this.

If you are not a fan of RWBY but are a fan of hack and slash games you will enjoy this greatly!

Cons:

- Animation sometimes bugs out but not very often.

- Some of the talking is to quiet. However this seems to be because the characters VA didn't do the lines so they made them quieter as to be less noticeable.

- Performance is a issue the game has yet to be optimized as it just came out of beta today but its still playable.

- No remapping of controls.

- It has its fair share of glitches none game breaking (But some come close IE. Your chat window goes away and won't come back)

Pros:

+ Sound track! While most of the game has background music boss fights have songs from the RWBY OST.

+ Each character feels really different. I have seen people say this is not the case but I have played as all 4 that are out now and each one plays different.

Ruby plays as heavy damage and crowd control. Her abilities are tailored to be able to take on hoards head on.

Weiss plays as support. She can freeze enemies and knock them back away from her team which is helpful for reviving.

Blake is less straightforward. In the game you get special blips to use special moves. To get one blip you have to fill up the combo bar without getting hit. On her own she deals fast low damage but fills up her bar quickly. Her special attacks are pretty good ranging from crowd control to boss killing moves.

Yang plays as two ways that I have found. She is either crowd control or a tank. Her attacks and special upgrades allow her to take a lot of damage and when her Aura is depleted she gets a full special bar. This combined with high health and wide weapon spread makes her perfect to take enemies.

+ The upgrading. Each character has 3 specials and a general for upgrading. The specials vary from character to character but the general is mostly the same except for 2 upgrades special to each character.

+ Its a challenging game. Most of the Grimm are weak alone but can quickly overwhelm you. To add to that you have Major" Grimm which are much stronger versions and can be tricky on their own.

+ A good variety of Grimm to fight.

You have 5 types to fight each with three upgrades.

Creeps
Beowulfs
Boarbatusk
Ursa
And a new mutated nameless Grimm.

In the end I would give RWBY:GE a 8/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are a fan of the show, then you will definitely enjoy this game. Since it is on early access, it’s bound to have bugs and not all of the intended features will have been implemented yet. Right now, there is just a short unfinished campaign which you can play co-op.
Just as the developers have intended, there is a Left 4 Dead feel to it, though it doesn’t seem as replayable as L4D at the moment.
There have been complaints about sound etc. but these are bound to be fix in due time. Personally I did not experience many problems. Just occasional FPS lag and the running animation freezing. But seriously, you can deal with that.
This game is fun even in early access so you can only imagine the potential it has when it’s completed.
The game looks cool. It’s got a potato setting. The characters look cool. The environment is cool. The attacks are cool. What else can you ask for in an early access game?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very fun but i feel they should say it is in alpha stage, after beating the fourth lvl while in the middle of a dungion like area it just cuts off and goes back to the lobby screen. I screwd around for about 2 hours testing each character and then my friend and i did 2 man co-op and beat the game twice in 2 more more hours. the games graphics are great and the combat is very smooth,it is deff worth buying as long as they continue making lvls/story
+good smooth graphics
+decent controls and smoth fighting
+its RWBY
+nice challenge
+skill progression allow for some customization
-no explanation for anything in game
-no real character customization
-very hard to unlock everyones skills and can only get 9/10 skill points and it costs about 17 for every skill
-everyone but blake has basically the same aoe skill, and blakes aoe is almost useless
-for the game to be so short atm, there is no difficulty change and you lose your lvls after each play through
+you atleast dont have to re-unlock the ability to get the skills once you unlock them
+feels like a RWBY game should feel like
=could add equipment and maybe so town to to buy stuff etc to give it a more complete feeling
=should alow you to save character progress and have a harder difficulty for max lvled play throughs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of RWBY, just having a game of it is amazing!

Definately Recommended!

Main Pros I noticed

-AMAZING Visuals
I swear the scenery is A-MAZE-ING, also because there are some places that looks like u can go to but you can't making it like a maze

-Voice Acting is awesome
Not even kidding, its like the show but in a game... a badass game...

-nice action animation
press left shift, now, press it again...

-Combat is pretty slick
between spamming left click and 1,2,3 of course

-All this and its just been released!

Main Cons

-No tutorial to help explain the game or teach you how to play
I literally did not know that i can sprint for an entire game and just was way behind my team until i looked at the controls

-XP Gain
uhhh, so I'm not too sure but it seems like you don't share XP normally with the exception of artifacts and such so if you just happen to not get the kills, you will be way behind everyone else.
XP is also given to MVP of waves and it makes the co-op not very co-op like~

All in all, its gonna be an AWESOME Game if the developers continue to work on this to the end!
[so look at the discussion area for their social media accounts and spam them :D Just kidding but it might be nice to thank them :P]
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Day 1 Review]
As a fan of the series I have to say that the game is really enjoyable and a fun experience overall.

I recommend purchasing the game only if you don't mind getting an incomplete and unoptimized game.

Pros
+ original voice actors
+ pretty visuals (the textures are a bit lacking tho, but you really don't notice that between fights)
+ simple skill/progression system (some more complexity wouldn't hurt)
+ potato quality
+ MORE RWBY!

Cons
- currently only has 4 chapters
- the music and voice volume is inconsistent
- can't remap controls
- graphical bugs, invisible walls (at the end of the first chapter in the final room near the secret area)
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I gotta say, after finishing Chapter 1... I'm already in love with this game. This is very smooth and plays like a true hack-n-slash.  I found loving how all 4 played, and neither of the 4 are dull. They all have their strengths and amazing abilities. I'll cut it short and put into a bulleted list.

Pros:
-Game runs VERY smoothly.
-Controls don't feel clunky or terrible.
-The characters, even though there are 6 (Ruby, Blake, Weiss, Yang, Oobleck, and Port), are perfectly acted.
-Much replayability to get all abilities and hear all the unique dialouge.
-Multiple abilities for each character.
-Tense battles.
-Very few bugs.

Now I could go on and on about the pros, but that's to long of a list.

Cons:
-Graphics can glitch sometimes.
-Auto Aim is unbearable.
-Number of enemies can get extreme sometimes.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery addicting to say the least but it can be repetitive sometimes. The repitition is about the only negative aspect about this game I can find. All the characters are unique and fun to play, and everything is fairly well balanced. Joining a game is seemless and I haven't encountered any game breaking bugs or glitches. I look forward to seeing hopefully more levels and more teams (JNPR!!!). Great work Rooster Teeth.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's a very fun game, full stop. Controls for both keyboard  and controller are nice and smooth, and the graphics are very nice to look at, and I get a stable framerate. All of these are provided there are no latency problems. There are some little problems which I expect from an early access game. Things like walk animations and transitioning between different attacks sometimes don't end when they should, but nothing really game breaking. Solid showing so far
